  Cresson , Member of the Commission. – (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to thank the European Parliament for its keen interest in relations between the European Union and Ukraine. The reports we are discussing today are to be commended, as is the work of the two rapporteurs.

Let me comment firstly on Mr Titley"s report regarding the action plan for Ukraine. The partnership and cooperation agreement with Ukraine, which came into effect on 1 March 1998, has opened a new chapter in relations between the Union and that country. It should enable a strengthening of cooperation in many spheres, not least political and economic.

The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement is a way of bringing the European Union and Ukraine closer. This requires substantial effort on the part of the latter in order to harmonize many legislative and administrative practices. Closer association with Ukraine could take the form of a free trade area, as provided for in the PCA, when structural reform in Ukraine is sufficiently advanced.

The first meeting of the Cooperation Council between the European Union and Ukraine will take place next June, and that of the first interparliamentary committee as soon as possible. An independent Ukraine is faced with three major issues: sowing the seeds of democracy; establishing its independence and unity; and putting a market economy in place. The balance sheet so far is encouraging with regard to the first two aspects and worrying regarding the third. Ukraine has put in place the foundations of a democracy and strengthened its international position. The signing of a Friendship Treaty with Russia in May 1997 has contributed to a stabilization of relations between these two countries, whilst the signing of a special partnership charter with NATO in July 1997 has helped the integration of Ukraine into a Euro‐Atlantic security bloc. Nevertheless, Ukraine is at a crucial stage in its economic transition. The European Union and international donors as a whole are concerned about the blockage in economic reforms and hope that the outcome of the elections on 29 March will enable an essential revival of such reforms.

The many commercial problems between the European Union and Ukraine illustrate the inadequacy of its economic restructuring. A team from the Commission is in Kiev this week to discuss these issues, particularly the situation of the motor market, which runs the risk of being closed to foreign producers.

The action plan for Ukraine was above all a political document in response to a Ukrainian request and its implementation is progressing satisfactorily. The actions being developed by the Commission largely match the recommendations in the Titley report. In particular, the Commission is in complete agreement with the importance of the development of civil society in Ukraine. That is the second recommendation. A joint mission with the United States is currently working on the preparation of a support programme for Ukrainian civil society, thanks to Parliament"s amendment to put ECU 2.5 million aside for joint actions with the United States in the former USSR.

Politically, it is extremely important to move the Chernobyl issue along. As you know, the agreement with Ukraine anticipates the closure of Chernobyl in the year 2000. The implementation of this agreement is progressing. Last year, the Commission proposed additional financing of ECU 100 million for the sarcophagus and we hope that the European Parliament will support us at the next part‐session by giving its assent. At the same time, the Commission continues to provide aid for the reform of the energy sector in Ukraine, which has been a priority for Community assistance right from the start. This position fits in well with that of the G7, which established a link between actions supporting the closure of Chernobyl and the long term reform of Ukraine"s energy sector.

I would now like to share with you our reaction to Mrs Hoff"s report, presented by Mrs Mann, which is primarily concerned with nuclear safety in Ukraine. I would first of all like to thank Mrs Mann for all the attention that she – along with Mrs Hoff – has given to the situation of the TACIS programme in Ukraine. I can assure you that this report has caused us to reflect internally on both the substance and the management procedures of our programmes, particularly the nuclear ones.

Our reflections have led to the following conclusions. Firstly, as regards substance, actions that are more targeted towards sites must be undertaken, with priority given to the nuclear plants which pose the most problems. Greater emphasis must be placed on the management of radioactive waste. The Commission is thus in the process of developing a specific programme for radioactive waste in north‐west Russia, along with its Euro‐Arctic Council partners of the Barents Sea. We are also in the process of supporting the transfer of know‐how and technology through strengthened promotion of industrial cooperation. At this stage, we can already state that, within the framework of this reorientation, the Commission is firmly committed to the closure of Chernobyl in the year 2000, in accordance with the G7 Memorandum of Understanding.

On a procedural level, with regard to management procedures in particular, Mrs Hoff"s report has led to a certain number of measures which will enable an improvement in the coordination of the programme. The Commission will increasingly make use of framework contracts with a view to reducing programme fragmentation. This approach will have the added advantage of reducing delays in the implementation of projects which are attributable to Commission departments as well as reducing the number of contracts to be managed.

The Commission has also taken on other accompanying measures. It has created a group of high level advisors, whose main task will be to provide independent advice on the direction and implementation of programmes, as well as on the nuclear risks in partner countries and, furthermore, it has taken measures to strengthen internal coordination in the area of nuclear power.

In conclusion, with regard to the Titley report I would emphasize that there is agreement between the Commission and the rapporteur on the broad outlines of our strategy towards Ukraine. With regard to the Hoff report, the Commission is paying particular attention to the rapporteur"s observations, with the aim of improving our assistance.

  President . – The debate is closed.

The vote will take place tomorrow at 12.00 noon.


13. Consumer protection

  President . – The next item is the recommendation for second reading on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and Citizen" Rights, on the common position adopted by the Council with a view to adopting a European Parliament and Council Directive on injunctions for the protection of consumers" interests (C4‐0585/97‐96/0025(COD)).

  Verde I Aldea (PSE), rapporteur. – (ES) Mr President, we are now at second reading of a directive which is of great importance despite its modest title.

Consumers have been paid special attention by the European Union and there are many directives granting rights to consumers. Nevertheless, these have always concerned with what I would call substantive rights, in other words, basic rights which have always been obstructed by the fact that there is a significant deficiency in this respect in the European Union. Judicial proceedings are not unified and there are very different legal and procedural systems throughout the various Member States.

This directive regulates procedural law for the first time and allows consumer associations to bring actions in any country of the Union. It sets out that as long as these organizations are recognized as such in a country, they can bring an action against the infringement of the directives on substantive rights of consumers in any country. This, in my view, is a very significant step forward which should be emphasized since I believe it is a great surprise.

The second aspect I would like to point out is that this directive has involved at different levels a high degree of cooperation between the Commission – which drew up the first draft –, the European Parliament at first reading – in close cooperation with the Commission – and, finally, the Council"s common position. The common position has recognized the spirit of the work carried out by the European Parliament and, Mr President, I do not mind saying, has improved the technical aspect of this directive. The Council has carried out serious work and when it does this, we must recognize its efforts in the same way as we usually criticize it at times for its inefficiency in other areas.

Therefore, given the serious work carried out by the Council, I proposed, and the Committee on Legal Affairs and Citizens" Rights approved this with a majority, not to introduce amendments at second reading and to accept the second reading as presented by the Council with its important aim, taking into account that the directive is acceptable, of speeding up as far as possible its implementation.

Nonetheless, some amendments have been tabled, in spite of this request, in reference to the fact that traders and industrial associations, amongst others, are not included in the directive. It is true that their interests could be defended in the same way as consumers" interests, but they do not in fact form part of the group we know as consumers, which is the subject of the list of directives in the Annex. For these reasons, Mr President, I recommend to the House that we adopt this directive and reject the amendments tabled, since I believe that it is an acceptable directive and Parliament should be satisfied with the work it has done in cooperating to ensure that this directive progresses.

  Oddy (PSE). – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work on an important Commission proposal. It is an important plank in the protection of consumers and consumer associations. It is an important project for the third pillar on cooperation on judicial affairs. Up until now we have had very few proposals in this area and therefore I particularly welcome this one.

It gives consumers the possibility of obtaining an injunction for an infringement of certain Community directives. I am pleased that the Commission recognizes the sagacity of Parliament's work and accepts 17 out of 20 amendments tabled by Parliament in the first reading and thus avoids the need for conciliation. I agree with Mr Verde that the sooner this directive is implemented the better.

With the increased mobility of tourism, educational visits and business travel, the need for cross‐border consumer rights is magnified. There is just one particular point that I would like to flag up. I know that the Consumer in Europe Group is disappointed that one amendment was not re‐tabled. However, I agree with Mr Verde that it was better to progress this directive as quickly as possible. However, the directive, as it currently stands, is only applicable to directives listed in Annex 1 and there are a number of directives they would have liked to have seen within the ambit of this directive, such as toy safety, low voltage gas appliances and personal protective equipment.

I would therefore respectfully suggest to the Commission that when this directive is fully implemented it reviews the working of this directive and looks at the possibility of extending the directive in the future to such matters as guarantees and distance selling of financial services, so that the very maximum benefit can be obtained for consumers.

  Palacio Vallelersundi (PPE). – (ES) Mr President, I am speaking tonight on behalf of my colleague, Mr Añoveros Trias de Bes, and on behalf of the Group of the European People"s Party. I would like to begin by highlighting, as the rapporteur did, the work carried out by the Council. In many ways, the common position improves on the ideas thrown in the ring by Parliament at first reading. This is a fact which must be recognized.

Nevertheless, the Group of the European People"s Party has tabled four amendments, which bring together most of the ideas approved at first reading and recognized by the Commission in its amended proposal. The Group of the European People"s Party is presenting them once again for several reasons.

Firstly, they concern respect for the field of application. Without entering into comments on what Ms Oddy said concerning the advisability of including other directives, for example on toy safety – despite the fact that we agree with her in the Group of the European People"s Party – I must point out that Article 1 establishes a limited scope, which could even be described as sectoral in nature. Only the needs of consumers are taken into account and those of businesses, tradesmen and the professions, collective interests which are considered in the list of directives in the Annex, are left to one side. Mr President, regardless of the legal scope of the different Member States, you will see that this will only serve to create even more legal uncertainty. The interpretation of what the collective interest of consumers is and that of businesses is not going to be the same in Spain as in Germany. We are now drawing up a new directive on this which, rather than bringing coordination and harmonization, will lead to insecurity, and the Group of the European People"s Party is going to retain this amendment even if it is not accepted, as a token and as proof of this belief.

Secondly, also concerning the field of application, I must state that there is no sense in separating the interests of consumers and the interests of other collective organizations recognized in those directives since, in fact, its aim is to enhance the smooth running of the internal market. Similarly, there is no sense in the other discrimination which is made whereby it is implied that the interests of consumers can only be defended by consumer organizations. This is totally false and incorrect.

Article 3, in fact, which is legally incorrect, at least in Spanish, talks about “finalidad’, or purpose. It should instead use “objeto’ or object. In Spanish law “finalidad’ does not exist. Purpose has internal scope. What counts when setting up an association or any kind of body is its object.

Let us take the example of the first directive listed, concerning misleading advertising. Is it the case that an employers" association from a country, for example Spain, cannot legitimately defend the interests of German consumers against the practice of a company from whatever country is involved, let us say Spain again, or that a German employers" association cannot defend the collective interests of consumers from another country? I believe that in this case we are creating false legitimacy which will also lead to legal insecurity during implementation. Since the ad causam interest – not the ad processum interest –, in other words, the legitimation of cause, is left to the Member States, nor will we interpret in the same way what the interest of a certain association is.

The third amendment concerns paragraph 1; the fourth amendment concerns Article 6 and is related to the two previous ones.

Mr President, the Group of the European People"s Party is in favour of this directive. We agree with this report but we must remember that there are problems involved and these will become evident over the next five years.

  Thors (ELDR). – (SV) Mr President, our group also welcomes this directive. As Ms Oddy and the rapporteur said, this directive on legal cooperation is great news for us. Personally I have become increasingly frustrated by the fact that we get quick cooperation in the first pillar to protect economic interests, but when we need protection through legal cooperation, often for the express purpose of protecting the citizens, it is difficult to bring about, which sometimes contributes to creating a false picture of the Union and its aims.

I believe, as the rapporteur said, that it is important that the directive can come into force quickly. Apart from the situations mentioned by Ms Oddy, the whole issue of telemarketing, for example, is important.

The few times when I have the opportunity to watch television, I am increasingly surprised by how even in Scandinavia, in Finland, where such misleading advertising is banned, I can see, for example, advertisements for things which can turn any old clumsy oaf into a nymph using the most fantastic fitness concoctions. I think it is important for consumer organizations and the authorities, for example, to be able to do something about this. It is also important for us to include the applicant countries in this process, because I see that marketing of this type also comes via these countries.

However, I regret that the European consumer organizations are not getting the right to represent consumers in the way we proposed, and that the field of application was restricted. In order to push this directive through quickly, we are supporting the rapporteur. However, our group does not support the amendments proposed by the Group of the European People"s Party. I also think that we would have just as many legal difficulties defining what type of organizations were taken into consideration in the proposal. We are therefore going to support the rapporteur's report.

  Graefe zu Baringdorf (V). – (DE) Mr President, on the subject of consumer protection and its legal possibilities, I should like to address a wider issue: the current situation with regard to animal feed. Since 1 April 1997 it has been obligatory to administer animal feed in accordance with a specific regulation. Although this is a matter of Community law, it is not being applied by the Member States. Our view – which I would like to discuss for the first time this evening – is that where consumers" health is threatened the Commission must have the right to intervene and withdraw from circulation any product that might prove dangerous.

In the case of BSE it is clear the origin lies in contaminated animal feed. However, the Commission is unable to intervene. We have asked the legal service of the European Parliament and the Commission to do something in this regard so that we can take a political initiative, so that the Commission can take action against the Council which is failing to observe its own laws in the Member States, to ensure that consumer protection measures can be implemented in the various areas.

  Habsburg‐Lothringen (PPE). – (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday during the debate on the MAI, I emphasized that the economy must first and foremost serve the people. Naturally, this applies to the directives we issue. At first reading, the European Parliament accepted several amendments to the specific directive which went beyond the remit of consumer interests to include the public interest and the interests of persons carrying on activities in commerce, industry and trade. However, it is unacceptable that, where legal action brought by organizations is permitted, if negative behaviour has an effect in another Member State, only consumer interests are taken into account. Such negative behaviour, as the Commission established two years ago, is detrimental to the smooth running of the internal market and leads to a distortion of competition to the disadvantage of the great majority of businesses which respect national legislation. These distortions, in turn, have an adverse effect on consumer confidence and therefore run contrary to the interests of the public.

Time and again in the various reports we see that it is in the interests of the Union, in other words, of the public, to formulate regulations in the general good. Nevertheless, we are quite resolute in our objection to any form of interference in national codes of procedure under the cover of consumer protection policy. Various countries, not least Germany, have decided against legal action brought by organizations. For this reason we wish to ensure that the aim of this directive is the harmonization of regulations in the interests of consumers, persons involved in commerce, industry or trade and the public interest. However, in order to secure the trust mentioned previously, it is also necessary to include unfair effects on competitors in the definition of infringements against this directive.

To use the language of political opposites, it is not a question of consumer interests in the spirit of the theory of class struggle, but a definition of the consumer as it is used in business where total quality management is the order of the day. And it is not only a one‐way street, everyone involved is included.

  Cresson , Member of the Commission. – (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission is extremely pleased with the progress regarding the proposal for a Council Directive on injunctions for the protection of consumers" interests which, only two years after its presentation, has arrived at a part‐session of the European Parliament for second reading. It is also pleased with the extremely positive results of the inter‐institutional cooperation, which have enabled the drawing up of a common position by the Council and its approval by Parliament"s Committee on Legal Affairs and Citizens" Rights, which shows a high degree of consensus on the protection of the collective rights of consumers.

Considering the innovative character of the mechanism the directive aims to introduce, an initial evaluation of its impact is anticipated two and a half years after its implementation by Member States. It will thus be possible to plan for the adjustments which will be necessary in the light of specific experience.

With regard to the last eight amendments, I have to say that they are the same as some of the amendments which have already been discussed within the Committee on Legal Affairs and Citizens" Rights. Some of these amendments, in particular Nos 1, 3 and 5, hark back to the debate which has already taken place within the said committee. They could well challenge the extremely realistic conclusions reached by the committee. Indeed, as the Committee on Legal Affairs concluded, the two‐stage mechanism of the common position is balanced and realistic. This mechanism consists of considering the possibility of including the collective interests of others as well as consumers in the injunctions: businesspeople, tradespeople, craftspeople and so on. That would take place two and a half years after the implementation of the directive and on the basis of a Commission report, in order to take into account both the current reticence of some Member States and the experiences gained during the first phase of the directive"s application.

That is why, on behalf of the European Commission, I consider it appropriate to keep to the conclusions of the Committee on Legal Affairs and Citizens" Rights, which has already rejected these amendments, thereby demonstrating an understanding of the importance of a rapid approval of this proposal for a directive.

With regard to Amendment Nos 2, 4, 6 and 7, insofar as they aim to establish links between national law and the capacity of qualified entities to act, as well as apprehend offenders, these amendments are less drastic than the common position. Firstly, I find it difficult to believe that Parliament would be less favourable to the protection of consumer interests than the Council. Secondly, these amendments bring into question the very purpose of the proposal for a Directive, that is to say, the mutual recognition of qualified entities to bring an action against an offender.

Furthermore, the notion of a breach of the measures for implementing European directives cannot be left to national law alone to deal with. That is why the Commission recommends that you retain the text of the common position, as approved by the Committee on Legal Affairs, by rejecting the amendments in question.

In conclusion, I would like, firstly, to thank the rapporteur, Mr Verde I Aldea, for his excellent work and for his contribution to the rapid progress of this proposal and, secondly, to invite you to follow the move initiated within the Committee on Legal Affairs by approving the common position. This will enable us to reach an important stage in European consumer protection and to give a significant response to the protection of collective interests which is targeted through this European legislation.

  President . – The debate is closed.

The vote will take place tomorrow at 12.00 noon.

(The sitting was closed at 11.50 p.m.)


ANNEXES

Annex I – Formal sitting

 

IN THE CHAIR: MR GIL‐ROBLES GIL‐DELGADO
President

(The formal sitting was opened at 12.00 noon)

Address by Thomas Klestil, President of the Republic of Austria

 

  President . – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a real honour for me to welcome you today to the European Parliament, the Community institution which represents all the citizens of the European Union. It is an honour and gives us great political satisfaction, since your presence here with us today emphasizes how fully your country has become integrated into the European Union.

Austria"s accession and its integration into the institutions of the European Union have taken place so smoothly that it is easy to imagine that it has been a member for a long time, when in fact it has only been here for just over three years.

Your visit is also a reminder that in July Austria will assume its first term of Presidency of the European Council and the Council of Ministers of the European Union. Any potential difficulties associated with taking up the Council Presidency so soon after your country"s accession have been amply compensated for by your hard work during the last three years.

It is with genuine admiration that we observe how Austria is preparing for its Presidency in the same careful, meticulous way it prepared for accession. Mr President, the second half of 1998 will be a time of great political challenges. Undoubtedly, one of the most important will be the accession negotiations with the countries of central and eastern Europe. Austria has a particular understanding of matters concerning relations with the new democracies of eastern Europe, thanks to the attention paid by successive Austrian governments to relations with those states. So we should be very glad that for those particular months the European Union will be able to benefit in a very special way from Austria"s knowledge in that area, and the experience it has gained from its own history.

There are few countries as deeply European as Austria. There are few things as difficult as trying to explain European history without also explaining the history of Austria. That is why we felt something was missing during those years when Austria was not a member of the European Union. I am happy to be able to say now that accession, like all those which have taken place and all those yet to come, was a major gain both for Austria and for the other Member States of the Union.

I conclude, Mr President, by taking advantage of your presence here to thank the people of Austria for the significant contribution they are making to the Europe of solidarity and peace we all long for.

President Klestil, you now have the floor.

(Applause)

  Klestil , President of the Republic of Austria. – (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it gives me great pleasure to have this opportunity to address you just a few months before the start of the first Austrian Presidency of the European Union.

During my visit to the European Parliament in December 1992, I spoke of what I felt were the essential foundations of a future unified Europe, and most importantly of a Europe of common values and a Europe of the people.

Since then Europe has changed considerably and at speed. Today the European Union is more than ever the centrepiece of a new European order. It is still my belief, however, that those basic elements have not lost their topical nature. They still have a vital role to play in determining the path towards a future unified Europe. This is particularly true of the Europe of the people whose active participation in shaping European unification, becomes, in my view, all the more indispensable as the Member States move closer together.

As in other countries in the Union, many people in Austria have the feeling that “Brussels’ – and sometimes “Strasbourg’ too – are becoming too involved in their personal affairs. No doubt my country, like many others, still suffers from a lack of European consciousness, particularly in relation to the European institutions. This leads to defensive reactions and thus to a weakening of the public support needed for European unification.

Whilst the external appeal of the Union has increased, internal cohesion is threatening to decrease. European integration is currently less broadly supported than it was in the 1950s and 1960s. For the current generation peace within the Union has long been taken for granted. Instead of the high expectations of the past, we are now more often met with scepticism or even apathy. This worries me, for without the solid support of the public a common Europe will be built on rocky foundations.

I therefore believe that the Union must address the question of proximity to its citizens in a much more energetic fashion, and would like to share with you five specific thoughts on this subject.

Firstly, we must make it clear that the Union is there for its citizens and not the other way around. If people are to support and contribute to the European project, then their most pressing concerns must genuinely be placed at the forefront of the European agenda.

That is the central idea of the British Presidency. It will also be the primary concern of the Austrian Presidency.

With eighteen million unemployed in the Union, the creation of jobs must be Europe"s number one priority. The material and mental poverty which lies behind this figure is a constant indictment of the Union"s politicians and casts doubt upon its performance.

With the Treaty of Amsterdam and the employment summit in Luxembourg, the Union created a design and a set of tools with which to contribute more effectively to the fight against unemployment. We need suitable framework conditions which will make it easier for the economy to create new jobs. We must act quickly and with concrete measures!

The long‐term protection of natural resources is another pressing concern of the people of Europe. Only an active environmental policy can guarantee our high standards of living in the long term. This requires sustainable solutions to transport and transit problems, health protection measures and protection against nuclear risks.

During its Presidency, Austria will promote the very highest standards of environmental protection. In negotiations on global environmental issues, too, the Union must be prepared to lead from the front with courage and credibility.

In order to flourish, a peaceful society needs stability. The Union"s priorities must therefore include internal security and the fight against crime. It must take effective and decisive action against organized crime, illegal migration and the drugs trade. The courts and the police must finally form a united front which can act quickly and energetically in order to counter the highly developed operations of international crime organizations.

If we are successful in these areas we will be able to ensure that it is firmly established in the hearts of our citizens that open borders and open societies represent the growth of freedom and stability rather than a threat to security.

My second consideration relates to the Union as a Europe of common values. Europe stands for social and cultural values which form the foundations of our coexistence in peace and freedom and to which all nations have contributed with their creativity, their talents and their historical experience.

I believe without doubt that on these basic values we can build a strong European identity which respects and promotes both individual and common elements. The relevance of these values in European politics must be increased – both in our joint foreign and security policy and in the fight against all types of discrimination in our society.

I see the 50th anniversary of the acceptance of the Declaration of Human Rights as a particularly fitting occasion on which to establish human rights and human values even more strongly as the twin pillars of the European order.

The recent brutal and bloody events in Kosovo illustrate once again the direct link between the observation of human rights and international security and stability.

(Applause)

At the moment our task is to find a speedy and credible common European answer to this burning problem.

My third point relates to the rift which has grown between the institutions and the citizens of Europe – it must be reduced and finally closed. Proximity to the people and transparency must characterize the work of the Union in all its aspects. New standards of communication with its citizens must overcome the Union"s image as an anonymous and technocratic centre of power – as many currently see it – far removed form their own lives.

Real transparency means being able to see who is responsible for which decisions. Real transparency also means using language which people can understand. Finally, real transparency means clarifying where the specific opportunities lie for our citizens in terms of cooperation and codetermination.

Fourthly, we must entrench even further the democratic legitimacy of the Union. The Amsterdam Treaty provides for a considerable strengthening of the role of the European Parliament. Austria spoke up strongly in support of this principle at the Intergovernmental Conference. Today Parliament – as the only directly elected body of the Union – is a partner with the same equal rights as the Council in legislative matters.

And you, ladies and gentlemen, bear a growing responsibility as mediators of the democratic will of the citizens of the Union. Democracy is always difficult. It has to lay itself open to the judgement and the criticism of the people of Europe every day. That is difficult enough within the framework of the national structures. Your task here in the European Parliament is even more difficult, even more challenging, because you have to raise democracy to European level without losing contact with the people which form its base.

I should like to extend to you myself my very particular thanks for your commitment and for the creative and dynamic role which this House plays in the process of European unification.

Fifthly, the principle of subsidiarity must be implemented with even greater energy than before. Europe is about variety. Variety is one of its unmistakeable features and also its strength – in the wealth of its landscapes, its languages and its ways of life, in its traditions and its spiritual and cultural values.

All the peoples of Europe want and are entitled to safeguard their individuality and their identity. This reality must be considered at each level of integration. Decisions must be taken as near to the people as possible. Only matters which really belong at European level should be decided at European level.

The regions are one of the most important sources of variety in Europe. They are the building blocks of the European order. For their inhabitants they represent identity and home. Their effective integration into European policy gives the Union a higher degree of legitimacy.

In Austria, we believe that with our experience as a federal state and our federal tradition, we can make a useful contribution to the implementation of the principle of subsidiarity.

Ladies and gentlemen, I have quite consciously chosen relations between the Union and its citizens as the central theme of my speech here today because I believe that this link is the key to getting Europe accepted and making it work at this time of historical decision‐making.

A larger, united Europe will only continue to exist if it wins the approval and the trust of its citizens. This is particularly true for the implementation of the great European projects which have a tangible effect on the lives of each individual citizen.

This applies in a very special way to the long‐term project of enlarging the European Union. It must take place under a set of conditions which give the individual nations of Europe, which have coexisted independently for so long, the feeling that they are really welcome, and also rid existing EU citizens of their fears that everything which has already been achieved may be in jeopardy.

In only a few days time the step‐by‐step integration of our partners in central and eastern Europe into the Union will enter a new phase with the start of the accession process for these countries.

This process is not only a question of them taking over the “acquis communautaire’, but also, and in particular, of the development and revival of the idea of “civil society’ in the new democracies. Strong and lively democracies and flourishing market economies cannot exist without social structures and institutions which are both shaped and supported by the people.

The last meeting of eleven Central European Presidents, which was entirely devoted to this theme, showed exactly the extent to which they are aware of this need. During the fateful days of 1989, the peoples of central and eastern Europe showed their courage and their readiness to take on their responsibility for the future. For these countries, one of the most difficult tasks on the path to membership of the European Union will be the reawakening of this spirit of cooperation.

Of all the Member States, Austria will be the most affected by enlargement. We share half the length of our border with countries wanting to accede to the EU. For this reason it is not in our interests to remain forever one of the EU"s peripheral countries and so to have to live on a social border running right through Europe. We will only be able to take full advantage of our central position when our neighbours also become members of the Union.

However, it would be wrong and dangerous for all concerned if we were to underestimate the problems associated with enlargement and did not consider seriously enough the related concerns of many citizens. The difference between the level of economic development in the current Member States and the new democracies is still great. And for this reason enlargement must be carefully prepared and implemented to ensure that it brings the best possible results both for our future partners and for the current members. A continued programme of reforms in our neighbouring countries must guarantee that EU standards are maintained.

At the same time, the Union itself must become capable for enlargement by implementing reforms in its agricultural and structural policies, by making the necessary institutional changes and by introducing a new financial package for the years ahead.

Finally, appropriate transition periods and supporting measures to facilitate the changes will also be necessary. Here I should like to draw your attention to the Austrian proposals for support for border areas which have been submitted to Brussels.

Ladies and gentlemen, today the European Union faces the huge task of simultaneously securing both dynamism and stability in our continent. Only by achieving this can we rise to the challenge of globalization. And to do so we need the support of our citizens.

Bringing the new Europe closer to the people is therefore the most important goal for you, the elected representatives of the peoples of Europe, for my country, the Republic of Austria, and for our Presidency. Thank you for your attention!

(Lively and sustained applause)

  President . – Thank you very much, Mr President.

(The formal sitting was closed at 12.28 p.m.)

ANNEX II

 

I. Questions to the Council

 

Question No 14 by Astrid Thors (H−0205/98)

Subject: Authorization of the EIB to make loans to Russia

As is well known, the European Investment Bank is an important investment institution. It has been authorized by the Ecofin Council to finance projects in the countries applying for EU membership. However, such authorization does not enable it at present to make loans for projects in Russia, although it is important that it should be able to do so, not only as regards the trans‐European networks and investment in environmental projects but also with a view to Russia's general economic development. On several occasions, during bilateral talks with the Member States, Russia has also requested that such loan facilities be made possible.

The EIB's current authorization expires in January 2000, but it would be highly advisable to discuss the authorization of such loans to Russia before then.

Has the Council discussed the authorization of the EIB to make loans to Russia, and what steps will it take so that the EIB is authorized to make loans for projects in Russia?

Answer

As the honourable parliamentarian recalls, Russia has on several occasions requested that the lending facilities of the European Investment Bank should be extended to it.

While recognizing that investments are of great importance for strengthening economic relations between the European Union and Russia, the honourable parliamentarian is reminded that the European Investment Bank is a Community institution, the primary purpose of which is to finance the development of the Member States of the European Union, and which only to a limited extent operates outside the Union on the basis of specific decisions of the Board of Governors, taken unanimously. The Russian Federation's requests have been thoroughly discussed by the Board of Governors (consisting of the Ministers of Finance of the Union), but so far it has proved impossible to reach the necessary unanimity. An important element in these discussions was that there exist other financial institutions, such as the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), which specialise in lending to countries like Russia.

Nevertheless the European Union is strongly committed to assist the process of economic reform through the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA). The first meeting of the Cooperation Council between the European Union and the Russian Federation held on 27 January 1998 permitted an exchange of views on the question of EIB lending in Russia. The Russian side has been reminded that given ECOFIN's position and the EIB's present lending mandate it is impossible to give any new message on the extension of the EIB's remit to Russia in the next few years. However, it has been made clear that in any case it would be up to the Russian side to identify a project or part of a project of Community interest in Russia and to submit it to the EIB which would consider it in accordance with its Charter.

The Council underlines that the European Union will continue to give sustained support to the Russian Federation's economic reforms with all means already existing for this purpose. This is demonstrated by the important contributions of the Union through the TACIS programme, the EBRD, the wider World Bank Group, and, of course, the individual efforts of Member States.

***

Question No 15 by Niall Andrews (H−0212/98)

Subject: The future of the EU actions in favour of the disabled

Following the adoption by the Commission in January 1998 of the final evaluation report on the activities of Helios II (199396), the EU's third action programme in favour of the disabled which has a budget of ECU 37 m and which introduced several positive and successful initiatives, will the Council, under the U.K. Presidency, back a new HELIOS III programme, and will it give a signal to the Commission that it should proceed immediately with the task of preparing a third Helios programme as part of a positive commitment to creating a real citizens' Europe?

Answer

The Council understands that the Commission is taking stock of the experience gained under HELIOS II. The Council will wish to consider any proposals from the Commission.

Aside from the HELIOS programme, the Council is keen to further the interests of disabled people. That is why at Amsterdam last year the governments of the Member States agreed new Article 13 enabling the Council to take appropriate action, after consulting the European Parliament, to combat discrimination on the grounds of disability. A declaration was also agreed at Amsterdam requiring the institutions of the EU to take into account the needs of disabled people when taking action under the single market provisions of the Treaties.

The UK presidency will be holding a seminar in April for high‐level officials to discuss Article 13.

The Employment Guidelines for 1998 also include a reference to disabled people. This required Member States to consider the needs of disabled people in the context of their employment strategies.

***

Question No 16 by Gerard Collins (H−0214/98)

Subject: Fifth Research Framework Programme

Following the recent and long awaited decision of the Research Council on the Fifth Research and Technological Framework Programme (1998‐2002), will the Council indicate the future role it foresees for research in the field of health including chronic diseases (cardiovascular), training and mobility for researchers and, in the context of the ageing population, does it envisage the participation of carers in this programme?

Answer

The Council agreed a Common Position on the Fifth Framework Programme (FP5) on 12 February. This agreement was not really ‚long‐awaited’ considering that the complete Commission proposal was available only in August last year and that the European Parliament's opinion was delivered only on 18 December.

Health research will indeed be an important area in the 5th Framework Programme. The thematic programme ‚Quality of life and management of living resources ’ is devoted almost entirely to health matters. Research into chronic and cardiovascular diseases is included within this thematic programme, the emphasis being on improved diagnosis, prevention and surveillance. The programme also includes a specific key action on the ageing population , on the lines suggested by the European Parliament in its first reading opinion. This key action recognizes the high burden on society, families, individuals and their carers of long‐term illness. It includes research into the effective and efficient delivery of health services and long‐term care.

Training and mobility of researchers in all fields will remain a priority in the Fifth Framework Programme. The Council has approved the Commission's proposal for a scheme of ‚Marie Curie’ fellowships to support young researchers working in Member States other than their own. Research training networks will be set up on topics chosen by the researchers themselves.

As the honourable Member will be aware, the Council's Common Position is, of course, subject to agreement by the European Parliament in its second reading under the co‐decision procedure.

Question No 17 by Jan Andersson (H−0218/98)

Subject: Initiatives to be taken by the Council at the UN Special Session on Drugs

In its work programme, the UK Presidency highlights drugs as one of the issues it intends to address during its term of office and mentions the need for it to play a coordinating role at the UN General Assembly Special Session on Drugs.

What initiatives will the Council support at the UN Special Session on Drugs, for example as regards the need for measures to combat the production and trafficking of synthetic drugs?

Answer

The Council reiterates its active support for the work currently under way in preparation for the UN Special Session on Drugs (UNGASS) (8‐10 June in New York). Considerable progress has been made in a number of areas, including precursors, synthetic drugs, money laundering, demand reduction and alternative development.

The European Union, under the Dutch, Luxembourg and now the UK Presidencies, has taken a prominent role in these negotiations.

The EU will support all of these initiatives which make useful and realistic steps forward in the fight against drugs. We welcome, in particular, the new initiative ‚Guiding Principles on Demand Reduction’ which is a new step for the UN in tackling drugs.

We also welcome the progress made against money laundering which brings a little nearer the endorsement by all States of the 40 recommendations of the Financial Action Task Force as the global structure for anti‐money laundering action.

Question No 18 by Per Stenmarck (H−0222/98)

Subject: Environmental destruction in the Baltic Sea

The UK Presidency has proclaimed the environment to be a top priority on the agenda for the first half of this year.

The Baltic Sea faces very major problems with continual oil discharges from vessels when, for example, cleaning out their tanks.

Is the Council ready to help make it a requirement for all countries around the Baltic Sea to create facilities in their ports for receiving such oil?

Answer

The British presidency will continue to support any workable measures that will reduce the amount of waste discharged by ships in all waters of the European Union.

As the honourable Member will be aware, the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution by Ships (MARPOL 73/78) specifically requires all countries around the Baltic Sea Special Area to ensure the provision of facilities adequate for the reception and treatment of all the dirty ballast and tank washing water from oil tankers as well as other residues and oily mixtures.

The Commission is currently drawing up a proposal for a directive on shore reception facilities, which may need to go further than MARPOL to meet fully the needs of mariners for adequate reception facilities. We hope this will be ready for debate at the June Council.

We also need to work internationally to address possible shortcomings in waste reception facilities outside the European Union. The International Maritime Organization will examine proposals to address the inadequacy of waste reception facilities at the 41st meeting of the Marine Environment Protection Committee to be held from 30 March to 3 April.

Question No 19 by Lone Dybkjær (H−0224/98)

Subject: Council's request for a more specific question

In its answer to Question No. H−120/98, the Council confirms its aim of reducing the distance between citizens and the EU. With regard to the particular directive which I criticized in my question as being unnecessarily incomprehensible, the Council replies that it is difficult to express a view without specific examples. To appreciate the full extent of the problem, the reader needs to sit down with several different documents. Why have the relevant documents not been compiled into a single, clearly arranged document?

Answer

The detailed control of food additives inevitably involves long technical lists, and the use of annexes is the most logical way to present these.

However, the Council intends, in its Common Position to propose some reordering, renumbering and redrafting of the various proposed amendments in the interests of consistency, and to bring them more in line with the layout of the existing directive. This should make the legislation clearer.

Question No 21 by Alexandros Alavanos (H−0234/98)

Subject: Letter from the President‐in‐Office of the Council concerning Cyprus accession negotiations

In a letter sent to Mr Kleridis following his re‐election as President of the Republic of Cyprus, the British Prime Minister and President‐in‐Office of the Council, Mr T. Blair, noted with reference to the negotiations for the accession of Cyprus that: 'an offer which fully takes into account the legitimate desire of Turkish Cypriots to be treated as political equals will contribute to the attainment of the objectives that we share....'.

What does the Presidency understand by 'political equality'? In the event of a failure to reach agreement, does the Presidency share the view that 'negotiations should begin with the Government of the Republic of Cyprus, which is the only authority recognized under international law'?

Question No 22 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−0261/98)

Subject: EU Presidency statements regarding equal treatment of Turkish Cypriots in Cyprus accession negotiations

Recent statements by senior EU Presidency officials and the Mr Blair's letter to the newly elected President of Cyprus, Mr Kleridis, have given rise to concerns about the unity and indivisibility of the Republic of Cyprus with the opening of negotiations for the accession of Cyprus in view. The appeals by the EU Presidency – which is also one of the 'guarantor powers' – to take 'full account of the legitimate desire of Turkish Cypriots to be treated as political equals' could be construed as appeals for the de facto recognition of the so‐called Turkish Cypriot state.

Does the Council consider that such statements are consistent with UN and EU Summit decisions hitherto and that they do not undermine the negotiations. Are they not contrary to international law and do they not tend to diminish the authority of the Republic of Cyprus and the Cypriot Government as the only legitimate representative of the Cypriot people?

Joint Answer

The letter by Mr Blair to the newly elected President of Cyprus, Clerides, fully respected the spirit of the Luxembourg Council, which expressed the EU's desire for Cyprus' accession to benefit both communities on the island, and to contribute to the search for a political solution to the Cyprus problem. In this context, the European Council requested that the willingness of the Government of Cyprus to include representatives of the Turkish Cypriot community in the accession negotiating delegation be acted upon. In order for this request to be acted upon, the necessary contacts are being undertaken by the presidency and the Commission.

Furthermore, the United Nations Security Council has repeatedly affirmed, most recently in its resolution 1146(1197) of 23 December 1997, that a Cyprus settlement must be based on a State of Cyprus with a single sovereignty and international personality and a single citizenship, with its independence and territorial integrity safeguarded, and comprising two politically equal communities as described in the relevant Security Council resolutions, in a bi‐communal and bi‐zonal federation, and that such a settlement must exclude union in whole or in part with any other country or any form of partition or secession.

The European Council has already agreed to convene a bilateral intergovernmental conference with Cyprus on 31 March 1998.

Question No 23 by Richard Howitt (H−0235/98)

Does the Council agree that full consultation but timely agreement of the final regulations are both essential if new programmes are to be prepared in time to avoid the excessive delays experienced after 1994?

Answer

The Council will determine the precise handling for consideration of the proposed Structural Funds regulations once it receives them from the Commission, in accordance with Article 130d and the other relevant articles of the EU Treaty.

The Commission proposals will be sent to the Committee and the Economic and Social Committee, as well as to the European Parliament and the Council.

Individual Member States will also be able to undertake appropriate local, regional and national consultation on the draft regulations.

The honourable Member is correct in identifying the need for timely consultation and agreement on the regulations. This will include receiving an early opinion from the European Parliament on the main regulation and efficient cooperation on the other relevant regulations.

The EU Regional Approach to the former Yugoslavia is consistent with the Council's policy in relation to other regions of the world, namely to encourage close cooperation between countries of a region and to promote peace and stability through development. Question No 28 by Robert Evans (H−0248/98)

Subject: Free movement of third nationals

Would the Council inform me of what efforts they are making to enable the free movement of third country nationals travelling from one EU Member State to another?

Constituents have contacted me on many occasions after having experienced difficulties participating in school trips or other visits to the continent whilst being legally entitled to be in the UK.

Answer

In reply to the question of the Honourable Member, it must be stressed that the Council discussed in the past various initiatives aimed at facilitating travel of third‐country nationals from one Member State to another. An important initiative in this context is the Joint Action concerning travel facilities for school pupils from third countries resident in a Member State.

Because the granting of travel facilities for school pupils who are legal residents in the European Union is an expression of a policy pursued by the EU with a view to improving the integration of third‐country nationals, the Council adopted on 30 November 1994 a Joint Action concerning travel facilities for school pupils from third countries resident in a Member State.

As to the future, the Council is currently discussing the breakdown of the Schengen acquis necessary for the incorporation of Schengen. The exercise of incorporation of Schengen will cover, amongst other things, the movement of third country nationals.

Question No 29 by Heidi Hautala (H−0252/98)

Subject: Non‐disclosure to Parliament of arms export criteria

Under Article J.7 of the Maastricht Treaty 'The Presidency shall consult the European Parliament on the main aspects and the basic choices of the common foreign and security policy and shall ensure that the views of the European Parliament are duly taken into consideration. The European Parliament shall be kept regularly informed by the Presidency and the Commission of the development of the Union's foreign and security policy'.

Why has the Council not proceeded in accordance with this article in revising the criteria for the export of arms by Member States? Why, in defiance of this article, has the Council not submitted to the Members of Parliament the report on the revision of the arms export criteria adopted at the meeting of 14‐15 November 1996 of the COARM working party? Does the Council propose to submit to the Members of Parliament the proposal of the current Presidency for a set of rules on EU arms exports? Does the Council regard the choice between promoting human rights and trampling them underfoot to be a main aspect and basic choice of the common foreign and security policy?

Answer

All the EU Member States are committed to the eight criteria for arms exports identified by the European Council in 1991 and 1992, and base their national export policies on them. The Honourable Member is no doubt aware that the respect of human rights in the country of final destination is among those criteria, which correspond to the views expressed on several occasions by the European Parliament.

While the arms export policies, and therefore the implementation of the criteria, remain the responsibility of the Member States and of their national licensing authorities, the Council has indeed proceeded, at different levels and also in the framework of the CFSP Working Group on Conventional Arms Exports, to an analysis of these criteria; with a view to achieving a common understanding on their interpretation and, as a consequence, coordinated implementation.

The Council has not, at any rate, undertaken the ‚revision’ of the criteria mentioned in the Honourable Member's question. The proposal for a Code of Conduct for arms exports, strictly based on the abovementioned eight criteria, does not entail in any way a modification of the list of criteria or of the commitments undertaken by the Member States at the Luxembourg and Lisbon European Councils. It aims at reinforcing the exchange of information and the cooperation among Member States within the framework of CFSP and promoting a more coordinated implementation of the criteria at national level. This enhanced cooperation would also include a mechanism of consultation for the cases where a Member State envisages granting an export authorization for essentially the same transaction for which a licence has been denied by another Member State.

As the Honourable Member mentions in her question, and according to Article J.7 of the Treaty, the European Parliament is kept regularly informed by the Presidency and the Commission of the development of the several aspects of the Union's foreign and security policy.

This particular issue has also been addressed in numerous questions put to the Council in the past.

Subject: Driftnets

In a report drawn up in September 1994 and a resolution adopted in July 1995, the European Parliament expressed its support for a ban on driftnets. In addition to causing damage to fish stocks, these nets often lead to the capture of mammals and are difficult to control properly, as pointed out in various Commission reports.

Will the Council of Ministers approve the proposed ban on these nets at its next meeting, as called for by Parliament and in line with the Commission's proposal? If so, will it also introduce measures for the destruction of these nets and for the conversion of fishing fleets affected by the ban?

Question No 32 by Mark Hendrick (H−0256/98)

Subject: Implementation of Single Market Legislation

A major obstacle to the completion of the single market is the failure of Member States to implement and enforce existing legislation voted on by this House. Would the Council indicate which Member States are failing in this respect, and explain how it proposes to tackle a problem which is costing competitiveness and jobs across Europe.

Answer

Although some noticeable progress has been achieved lately with regard to transposition of Community internal market legislation into national law of the Member States we have not yet reached our target. The Council is very much aware that considerable efforts still have to be undertaken in order for internal market directives to be fully implemented and correctly applied in all Member States. This is crucial for a proper functioning of the Single Market and thereby also for our efforts to improve the conditions for economic growth and more employment in the EU.

As the honourable Member is aware the Commission is continuously monitoring progress regarding implementation and enforcement of internal market legislation which is an important part of the Action Plan for the Single Market. In the ‚Scoreboard’‐document, which was transmitted to the Council in December last year, the Commission presented a progress report on the implementation of the Action Plan with particular emphasis on transposition of Single Market directives as well as problem solving and enforcement. It concluded that although progress in implementing the Action Plan had been satisfactory so far a sustained political commitment is necessary to fill the gaps identified in the Scoreboard. As of 1 November 1997 26 percent of all internal market directives had still not been implemented by all Member States. In view of this situation in the Internal Market Council, at its meeting on 27 November last year, held a debate on the subject and called on the Member States ‚to mobilize all necessary resources to meet the commitments contained in the transposition timetables they had notified to the Commission...’.

Meeting informally in Cambridge on 13‐14 February, the EU Ministers in charge of the internal market and Commissioner Monti reviewed the situation. We were happy to note some progress with regard to transposition as compared to the figures contained in the Scoreboard. As of 1 February, the percentage of Single Market directives not implemented by all had fallen to 21 percent. Still a high figure but nevertheless an improvement compared to the situation three months earlier. There was a general agreement among Ministers at Cambridge that the efforts to implement the internal market legislation must be intensified so that we can achieve the objectives set out in the Action Plan for a well performing Single Market in time for the third stage of the EMU.

We also agreed that an improved quality of the Community legislation is an important factor which will greatly facilitate a correct application of the common rules. This aspect, together with simplification of legislation, is a matter of high priority for the United Kingdom presidency. We want to achieve more understandable, more user‐friendly and thereby also more effective legislation. The conference on ‚Better Government: more effective regulation’ which the presidency is organizing in Manchester on 9‐10 March will very much focus on these important aspects. It is also the intention of the presidency to revert to the matter of implementation and enforcement at both sessions of the Internal Market council this spring so the honourable Member can rest assured that the Council will continue to pay close attention to the need for further action in this field. There is a clear commitment by all Member States to speed up the process of transposition to the extent possible with due regard to constitutional and administrative constraints which no doubt explain quite a few of the delays which have occurred. We have also agreed to improve the cooperation between national authorities as well as with the Commission at different stage of the legislative process with a view to facilitating the implementation. Such measures, coupled with continued efforts of simplification, make me rather confident that we can expect further progress in the months to come.

***

Question No 33 by Katerina Daskalaki (H−0260/98)

Subject: Destruction and looting of monuments in Cyprus

Churches and cemeteries are constantly falling into ruin in the occupied sector of Cyprus; they are being looted and converted into stables without the international community being particularly moved or taking any action. Cyprus' permanent representative to the UN has also complained about this tragic situation. Once again, will the Council intervene, given that Cyprus is about to become a member of the EU and Turkey, which is maintaining the occupying forces, is associated by special agreements to the EU?

Answer

The Council regrets the above mentioned developments which are a direct consequence of the de facto partition of the Island. For the European Union, the best way to contribute to an alleviation of the problem is to continue its efforts to find a political solution to the Cyprus question.

The accession of Cyprus should benefit all communities and help to bring about civil peace and reconciliation. The accession negotiations will contribute positively to the search for a political solution to the Cyprus problem through talks under the aegis of the United Nations which must continue with a view to creating a bi‐communal, bi‐zonal federation as referred to in numerous UN Security Council resolutions. In this context, the European Council has requested that the willingness of the Government of Cyprus to include representatives of the Turkish Cypriot community in the accession negotiating delegation be acted upon. The necessary contacts are being undertaken by the presidency and the Commission.

As far as Turkey is concerned, the European Council meeting in Luxembourg on 12‐13 December recalled, in line with the Council position expressed at the Association Council with Turkey on 29 April 1997, that strengthening Turkey's links with the European Union will i.a. depend on Turkey's support for negotiations under the aegis of the UN on a political settlement with Cyprus on the basis of the relevant UN Security Council Resolutions. The Union has emphasized to Turkey that its aspiration to join the EU implies sharing the EU's major objective, of which the accession of unified Cyprus is one and good neighbourly relations another.

Question No 36 by Arthur Newens (H−0962/97)

Subject: Equal access to justice for EU citizens

What action is the Council taking and what steps does it envisage to ensure that individual European citizens who are arrested within the European Union but outside their own Member State are not subjected to refusal of bail, inordinate lengths of time on remand, difficulties in obtaining information in their own languages about the charges against them and the legal process under which they are tried, problems with defence lawyers and other forms of discrimination which would not be encountered in their own Member State?

Answer

Decisions concerning matters of bail, remand and other practical aspects of criminal proceedings in individual cases are, of course, for individual courts in Member States to take according to national law. National legislation and practice in these areas are subject to the provisions of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms of 4 November 1950, to which all Member States of the Union are party. Article 5 of this Convention requires that a person detained is informed promptly, and in a language he understands, of the nature and reason for any charge against him and is given the right to challenge the lawfulness of his detention. It also requires that the person concerned is brought to trial within a reasonable time or given (conditional) release pending trial, while Article 6 guarantees the person charged with the offence adequate time to prepare his defence. Article 6 also provides that the person charged has the right to choose his own legal assistance, or if he has insufficient means to pay for such assistance, to be given it free.

The Council takes this opportunity to underline the great importance it attaches to the protection of individuals and the need to preserve the values provided for in the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights. The adequacy of provision for interpretation facilities to those facing proceedings in an EU Member State other than their own is a matter which is being addressed by the current UK presidency; a questionnaire to all Member States on the provision of interpretation facilities is expected to be issued shortly as a presidency initiative.

Question No 37 by Jaime Valdivielso de Cué (H−0039/98)

Subject: Imports of wines departing from Community oenological practices

Could the Council say why it has granted a further year's extension in respect of imports of wines that have undergone oenological processes not provided for in Regulation (EEC) 822/87, (1) bearing in mind that the exceptions specified in Council Regulation (EEC) 1873/84(2) applied for a period ending on 31 December 1997?

Answer

The Council has decided, on a Commission proposal, to extend until 31 December 1998 the term of validity of the derogation for wines from certain third countries that have undergone oenological practices not allowed by Community rules.

The decision is linked to negotiations between the Community and the USA, which is the beneficiary of the derogation in question. These negotiations have been taking place for some considerable time. The Community's main objective is to obtain, as part of an overall agreement, protection for the Community's registered designations of origin and geographical indications for wine.

Both the Commission and the Council have expressed their firm intention to maintain pressure on the USA, in order to reach a satisfactory conclusion on this matter.

Question No 38 by Anne McIntosh (H−0070/98)

Subject: The future of the KONVER Community Initiative

In light of the review of the European Union's structural priorities, started by the Commission Communication Agenda 2000, what measures does the Council envisage being introduced to replace the Community Initiatives, especially the KONVER programme?

Answer

We expect the Commission to publish on or after 18 March draft regulations on the Structural Funds regime for the period 2000 to 2006. In Agenda 2000, the Commission suggested that the number of Community Initiatives be restricted to three fields:

‐ cross‐border, transnational and inter‐regional cooperation to promote harmonious and balanced spatial planning;

‐ rural development;

‐ human resources, paying special attention to equal opportunities.

The Council will consider the extent to which these Initiatives add value to the main Objective programmes, and how far the main Objective 2 programmes provide flexibility for Member States to target funds effectively at areas of need – such as those which have been subject to industrial restructuring, including areas dependent on the defence sector.

Question No 39 by Mark Watts (H−0085/98)

Subject: Pollution and premature death

A UK Government report has recently found that between 12 000 and 24 000 people per year die prematurely from the effects of pollution, most of which is caused by fumes from cars and lorries.

Research suggests that a similar problem exists throughout the EU. What action is the Council proposing to take to reduce the effects of pollution, particularly from cars and lorries?

Answer

Improving air quality is an important issue for the Council and a central part of the presidency's environmental objectives. The Council is considering the Commission's proposals for the first Air Quality Daughter Directive for sulphur dioxide, oxides of nitrogen, particulate matter and lead and is progressing all of the Auto‐Oil Directives. It adopted Conclusions on a Community strategy to combat acidification on 16 December 1997.

The Council recognizes the important synergies between environmental and transport measures, especially in improving air quality. During the UK presidency, the Council intends to hold two joint sessions of Environment and Transport Ministers: an informal session at Chester in April and a formal Council in June.

The Council has given a high priority to the Auto‐Oil Directives. The Auto‐Oil programme is a major Community initiative to tackle the problems of air pollution by vehicles, which the Council fully supports. All the elements of the programme are being negotiated and the Council looks forward to early adoption. The programme is fully in line with the Fifth Action Programme for Protection of the Environment which called for further substantial efforts to be made with a view to reducing pollution and thus improving air quality in the Community.

The Commission has brought forward four legislative elements which comprise the Auto‐Oil package. The Council has agreed a common position on the cars and fuels proposals – which tightened the Commission's proposals. The Council is considering Parliament's views concerning the car emissions and fuel quality standards common position. The Council hopes to reach a common position on the Commission's proposal for a Directive concerning emissions from light commercial vehicles at the Environment Council later this month. The Council has also begun discussion of the Commission's proposal for heavy duty vehicle emission standards, on which we expect there will be an orientation debate at the Environment Council in June.

Question No 40 by Mihail Papayannakis (H−0122/98)

Subject: PHILOXENIA programme

The PHILOXENIA programme states that the tourist industry plays an important role in job creation, particularly for groups of the population such as women and young people, and in attaining economic and social cohesion. The programme should have entered into force on 1 January 1997 following its adoption by Parliament(3) and favourable opinions from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions but it has been held up, largely owing to reservations by Germany and the UK, which is completely contrary to the conclusions of the Employment Summit held in Luxembourg in November 1997.

What is the reason for holding up such an important programme which is designed to improve the quality and competitiveness of European tourism? Will the Council say whether and when it will launch the programme and thereby stimulate development and employment?

Answer

As the honourable Member's question indicates, the Council has been discussing a Multiannual Programme to Assist European Tourism (Philoxenia) since 1996, without reaching an agreement. The Council does not intend to resume examination of Philoxenia at this stage.

However, the Council recognizes that the tourist industry has great potential for improving the economic situation and creating jobs.

At its meeting on 26 November 1997 the Council noted the presidency's conclusions on the Conference on Employment and Tourism held in Luxembourg on 4 and 5 November 1997. In particular, the Council confirmed in its conclusions that balanced and sustainable development of European tourism could make a significant contribution to combating unemployment in the Member States.

The Council therefore shares, as it has made clear on several occasions, the honourable Member's opinion regarding the need to exploit to the full, in the framework of the different programmes and policies, the contribution that tourism can make to job creation. In particular the Council recognizes the importance of the training of human resources.

The tourist industry also receives considerable aid under the Community's cohesion policy, by means of the Structural Funds.

2. Questions to the Commission

 

Question No 49 by Concepció Ferrer (H−0171/98)

Subject: Checks on animal cleanliness

When animals arrive at slaughterhouses they are covered in their own excrement. This leads to skin infections and damage to the hide, thus reducing the quality (and therefore the value) thereof.

The poor quality of European leather and raw hides costs the Member States' economies an estimated ECU 750 million per year.

In view of these facts, does the Commission not think that Community rules should be drawn up to regulate the state of cleanliness of animals when they come to be slaughtered?

Answer

It is certainly not the case that all animals arriving in slaughterhouses are covered with faecal material.

However, recently some cases of food borne diseases were reported which were suspected of being connected with poor hygiene working practices during production of meat. In order to solve these problems the Commission after consulting the Scientific Veterinary Committee agreed the necessity to amend Directive 64/433/EEC (’Fresh Meat Directive’) to include measures aimed at the reduction and control of contamination of animals on arrival at slaughterhouses. This proposal at present is discussed among experts at Commission level.

Although this initiative is taken to improve the hygiene quality of meat, it will also contribute to a better quality of hides and skins.
