Question No 50 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H−0183/98)

Subject: Direct subsidies to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe

According to the Commission's document on enlargement, Agenda 2000, when the applicant countries become members, they will not be granted direct aid in the form of area and headage payments. That will create a division between present and future Member States or, to put it another way, an A and a B team within the EU.

What are the Commission's reasons for not granting the east European countries direct subsidies? Does the Commission consider that there are problems involved in maintaining a common agricultural policy comprising common border protection and free trade in farm produce when, at the same time, not all Member States receive the common forms of aid?

Answer

In Agenda 2000, the Commission proposed that applicant countries should not receive any direct payments in the form of arable payments or animal premia after their accession. Under the CAP, these payments are regarded as compensatory allowances to offset price reductions that have already taken place in the European Union or loss of income as a result of proposals under Agenda 2000. These payments could not be justified for farmers in the acceding countries given that after accession they would in fact receive increased prices for their products and would therefore see an improvement in their income.

Regarding fears that common external protection and free trade in agricultural products could possibly be impeded by not granting direct payments, it should be borne in mind that direct payments are not price‐dependent and are therefore irrelevant for the free movement of goods.

Question No 51 by MaLou Lindholm (H−0187/98)

Subject: Checks on hemp growing

The EU reportedly subsidizes hemp growing in the Member States through its agricultural aid to France, Spain, the UK and the Netherlands inter alia. EU aid has helped to increase hemp growing from an area of around 9000 hectares (1995‐1996) to some 35 000 hectares (1998‐1999). Growers receive ECU 700 per hectare in aid. The total amount of subsidies involved is around ECU 15 million. A condition of receiving aid is that the hemp does not contain THC, i.e. that it is 'industrial' hemp and cannot therefore be used for intoxication. So far there is no proof, though rumour is rife, that 'marijuana hemp' is also being grown on EU‐subsidized land. Will the Commission therefore say how it checks that only industrial hemp is being grown and whether any cases of fraud have been detected in which EU aid has been paid to growers of hemp which contains unacceptable quantities of THC?

Answer

Community rules on conditions for granting aid to hemp are strict in various respects.

The granting of aid is limited to certified seed of varieties whose intoxicants (tetrahydrocannabinol) content is no greater than 0.3 %. For this purpose a Community list has been drawn up of varieties for which compliance with this criterion can be demonstrated using a Community method of quantitative chemical analysis. Furthermore, the rules prescribe that the official labels of the seed used must be available for inspection and that harvesting may only take place after seed formation.

The Commission knows of no cases in which Community aid had successfully been sought for hemp cultivation and was then in practice used to cultivate hemp for use as a drug. However, expert opinion is that, in theory, this risk cannot be ruled out under the present arrangements.

Finally, the Commission wishes to point out that there has been a deliberate expansion of the area of land planted with hemp in the EU, and that it has therefore proposed a 25 % cut in aid to this sector in the prices package.

Question No 52 by Esko Seppänen (H−0194/98)

Subject: Support for Finnish agriculture under a revised Agenda 2000

According to information from the Finnish Minister of Agriculture, the Commission is planning to revise Agenda 2000, as a result of which Finland would lose around ECU 150 million of its current EU support. Compensation would go to the wrong product as far as Finnish farmers are concerned: support for the price of maize feed. The situation is untenable from the point of view of Finnish agriculture: the entire countryside will become a wasteland. How will the Commission avoid a disaster along these lines, caused by a change in the EU's support policy?

Answer

Agenda 2000 proposes to exclude silage cereals from direct payments for arable crops. When discussing the Agenda 2000 orientations with Member States, the European Parliament and representatives of farmers' and other organizations, several arguments have been raised against this particular proposal. The most substantial concern was to avoid expensive control mechanisms and to maintain producer flexibility, since the final use of maize (grain versus silage) may depend on weather conditions which obviously cannot be foreseen when applying for the arable crop payment.

The Commission has taken into account all arguments and the critical attitude of most Member States concerning the exclusion of silage cereals when drafting the Arable Crop Regulation. However, the Commission will not decide before 18 March on the regulation proposals.

Question No 53 by Pat Gallagher (H−0206/98)

Subject: Sheep farming in hill and mountain areas

Has the Commission any plans to bring forward proposals to alleviate the very serious problems which sheep farmers in hill and mountain areas, particularly in Ireland, are experiencing at present and, if not, will the Commission now bring forward proposals to address the problems and issues of concern to sheep farmers including REPs and extensification?

Answer

The Commission accepts that sheep farmers in hill and mountain areas can have difficulties. However, it has not brought forward a proposal for the introduction of an extensification premium in the sheep sector, as one of the main reasons for the extensification premium for beef production mentioned in the question was to reduce overproduction in this sector. As there is no overproduction in the sheep sector, there is no general need to reduce stocking density. We do of course recognize that a reduction in stocking density in some areas of the Community would help to prevent overgrazing. This applies chiefly to communal lands in the west of Ireland. Some of the overgrazed land is in areas covered by the habitat and bird protection directive, and the Commission has indicated to the Irish authorities that remedial action is essential.

The current agri‐environmental programme in Ireland (REPs) includes measures for protecting natural habitats and overgrazed areas. However, these measures have been unsuccessful. Furthermore, an inspection visit in connection with the communal lands revealed that REPs had so far had no effect on these lands, which was a matter for concern. As the existing instruments for these areas are evidently unsuitable, the Commission has since requested Ireland to exclude the communal lands from the programme.

The Commission and the Irish authorities have at the same time entered into joint discussions with the aim of working out a targeted set of measures for all communal lands and natural habitats, including those subject to the habitat and bird protection directive.

Farmers are to be encouraged to manage their land in an environmentally sound manner and to take appropriate steps to guarantee regrowth of plant cover. However, in view of the polluter pays principle, the Commission cannot countenance rewarding farmers who have previously caused substantial environmental damage out of a pure profit motive. The agrienvironmental regulation provides for farmers to be compensated for environmental services that go beyond the minimum acceptable management methods. Discussions with the Irish authorities on this have not yet been concluded.

Question No 54 by Alexandros Alavanos (H−0208/98)

Subject: Reimbursement of withheld aid for cotton

The final quantity of aid‐eligible unginned cotton produced in Greece in the 1997/98 marketing year is approximately 1 080 000 tonnes. As the coresponsibility levy has been lowered, this means that some Drs 75 per kilo will have to be paid back to Greek cotton growers. Under the regulations, this sum will be repaid after July 1998. Greek producers are in dire financial straits, particularly as a result of a fall in production which in some regions (such as Thrace) is drastic, and they are not even able to meet the cost of cultivating their fields for the new year. Furthermore, cotton production will total no more than the original estimate of 1 100 000 tonnes and it would therefore be feasible, simple and absolutely devoid of any financial risk to retract the extra 15 % imposed on production which led to the increase in the aid withheld. In view of all these factors, will the Commission say whether it will amend the relevant regulations to enable producers to receive immediate payment of most of the money to which they are entitled for not having exceeded the stipulated quantity?

Answer

Since the reform applicable from the 1995/1996 marketing year on, EC regulations with regard to the payment of aid for unginned cotton have taken the form of a combined system of advance aid payments throughout the year, with the balance outstanding paid at the end of the year.

Advance aid payments are based on a stabilization mechanism applied to the estimated production before the start of the marketing year, and increased by 15 %. This percentage is a safety net to ensure that at the end of the year the advance payments do not exceed the final amount of aid to be paid.

The present system of payment of EC aid in two stages is still applicable during the 1997/1998 marketing year.

Further to the report submitted by the Commission to the Council in February on Greece's requests concerning the cotton industry, the creation of a legal framework is expected, and this would enable production to be re‐estimated, from the 1998/1999 marketing year on. This measure should make it possible to revise the advance aid payments so that producers can receive more quickly advance payments of amounts that correspond as closely as possible to their final entitlement.

Question No 55 by Marie‐Paule Kestelijn‐Sierens (H−0223/98)

Subject: Decision 97/584 on BSE risk material

Article 2 of Decision 97/584(4) states that the use of specified risk material 'for any purpose' is prohibited. Does this decision also apply to industrial products? Can the Commission clarify its answer to my question of 25 November 1997 (H−0881/97)(5) ? Can it indicate whether or not it will explicitly exclude industrial applications from the scope of this decision? When will the Commission take a decision? Can the Commission clarify why a decision or an opinion on this matter is not forthcoming?

Answer

On 30 July 1997 the Commission adopted Decision 97/534/EC, in accordance with the opinion of the Scientific Veterinary Committee. This requires the removal of certain tissues from bovine, ovine and caprine animals, which are designated as specified risk material (SRM) and must not be used for any purpose.

However, the Commission Legal Service has stated that a broad interpretation of the term ‚use for any purpose’ could mean that all products which contained or had been manufactured using SRMs could no longer be placed on the Community market. This was not the intention of the Commission since there is no scientific advice that all industrial products pose a risk to human or animal health.

On 25 February 1998 the Commission approved a proposal to amend Decision 97/534/EC including a provision to exempt the use of SRMs in several cases, including the manufacture of some industrial products. As the proposal has not received a positive opinion from the Standing Veterinary Committee on 4 March, the Commission has transmitted it to the Council. It is on the agenda of the Agriculture Council of 16 and 17 March.

Question No 56 by James Nicholson (H−0231/98)

Subject: Beef export ban

Following the Commission recommendation that the beef export ban should be removed from Northern Ireland, will the Commission inform Parliament what progress has been achieved and whether it is satisfied with the progress of the Scientific Veterinary Committee?

Question No 60 by Giles Chichester (H−0264/98)

Subject: The possibility of lifting the ban on British beef exports

What further measures does the Commission envisage must be taken in order that the ban on the export of beef reared in Devon and other parts of the UK can be lifted?

How soon does the Commission envisage this will happen? How do these measures fit in with Commission plans to deal with the structural surplus of beef in the EU?

Joint answer

The Commission has made a proposal, in accordance with the opinion of the Scientific Steering Committee, for a partial lifting of the restrictions on the dispatch of beef from Northern Ireland to other Member States and to third countries. As the proposal has not received a positive opinion from the Standing Veterinary Committee on 4 March, the Commission has transmitted it to the Council. It is on the agenda of the Agriculture Council of 16 and 17 March.

The United Kingdom authorities have also put to the Commission a proposal for a date‐based export scheme, which would apply to the whole of the United Kingdom and would permit the dispatch of beef from animals born after 1 August 1996. This is the date on which the transmission of BSE is considered to have been stopped, by full implementation of the ban on feeding mammalian protein to cattle.

The Commission is preparing a proposal based on the United Kingdom proposal, amended in line with the opinion of the Scientific Steering Committee. It is expected that the Commission will present its proposal to the Standing Veterinary Committee within the next few months.

Question No 57 by Hans Lindqvist (H−0246/98)

Subject: EU threat to Swedish seed varieties

Seed dealers selling varieties of vegetables not registered by the EU are being threatened with prosecution if they do not cease trading. Only plants on the EU's common list of varieties may be sold and, to be included in the list, a variety must have an owner. Ownership costs SEK 20 000 per variety.

So far, the Swedish authorities have confined themselves to appealing to firms to stop selling. A few firms have now been threatened with prosecution. Rimebergs Fröer in Spekeröd is to give their seeds away to avoid prosecution. Lindbloms Frö in Kivik, however, is apparently set to do battle with the authorities over the EU's rules. The case is about to be tried in the courts.

Is this really the right level of involvement for EU rules, preventing small‐scale seed processing which is often conducted by small or one‐man businesses?

Answer

Mr Lindqvist is referring to the EC directive on trade in vegetable seed. According to this directive, seed for a vegetable variety may only be placed on the market in the EU if it complies with the rules and is officially permitted in one or more Member States. In this way it is intended to ensure that only regulation quality seed is placed on the market, and that this seed can be freely marketed.

The existence of official catalogues of varieties is very useful for the agricultural sector in the Member States, as in this way good varieties are spread. Furthermore, catalogues of varieties, at least for cultivated plants intended for human consumption, are one of the best means of combating world hunger. Compulsory catalogues of varieties prevent unknown or unsuitable seed coming onto the market. Thus, a seed buyer who wants a certain vegetable variety can be certain that the variety name corresponds to the seed required.

As far as the Commission is aware, the system of having an official catalogue of varieties does not pose any threat to species diversity in vegetable varieties.

The 1992 directive on the marketing of vegetables and vegetable propagating material with the exception of seeds stipulates the introduction of implementing regulations for measures to preserve species diversity. In 1993 the Commission proposed to the Council that a provision to this effect should be included in the catalogue of varieties directive. At its sitting of 15 July 1997, the European Parliament adopted an opinion on this proposal. The Commission subsequently submitted an amended proposal to the Council, taking account of this opinion, which also included the preservation of genetic plant resources.

Question No 58 by Josu Imaz San Miguel (H−0254/98)

Subject: Milk

The Commission is planning to reform the common organization of the market in dairy products within the framework of Agenda 2000. However, it should be remembered that some Member States have a quota deficit and that milk producers have an important role in rural development, mainly in hill farming areas.

In the light of the above, will the Commission increase the existing milk quotas? If so, does it consider that this increase should benefit those Member States with a deficit, particularly hill farming regions, small producers and young farmers? Is it thinking of introducing an agricultural income based not on production but on the producer, so as to discriminate positively in favour of small farms, rural development and the social and environmental objectives of the CAP?

Answer

The Member States in general reacted positively to the Commission's proposals for reform contained in its Agenda 2000 document of July 1997.

However, they raised objections on a number of points and these have been carefully considered by the Commission.

In the dairy sector the Commission is anxious to reconcile the Member States' views and aspirations with consultations currently under way and with the proposals planned. This applies to the need for greater flexibility in the milk quota system against the background of the world market and trends in producers' income.

The Commission intends to propose a direct premium to compensate for the possible fall in income resulting from reduced price support. In order to take account of specific production conditions and guarantee well‐balanced support of milk and meat production, the milk production premium is to combine milk and meat elements. The Member States have thus been given sufficient scope to take account of their own circumstances and to adopt measures tailored to their requirements.

Question No 59 by Robert Sturdy (H−0263/98)

Subject: Underspending in the EAGGF budget 1996 and 1997

According to Diagram VIII of the European Court of Auditors report on the 1996 budget, the EC underspent the EAGGF budget by over ECU 2.2 b. in 1996. This resulted in significantly lower contribution to the 1997 EU budget by the Member States. In the light of this, could the Commission please clarify specifically which sections of the EAGGF were underspent in 1996? Furthermore, could the Commission please state to what extent the 1997 EAGGF budget was underspent and the subsequent effect of the underspend on Member State contributions in 1998, with specific reference to the United Kingdom?

Answer

First of all, the underspent of over ECU 2.2 billion of the 1996 EAGGF‐Guarantee budget mentioned by the honourable Member should be brought down to ECU 1.7 billion because it includes the monetary reserve (500 Mio ECU) which can only be spent under certain specific monetary conditions, which were not fulfilled in 1996. On the other hand, as can be seen in chapter 2 of the Court of Auditors' report, various chapters presented as underspent of which the sectors ‚arable crops’ (−650 Mio ECU), ’dairy products’ (−137), ’sheep and goat meat’ (−126), ’beef’ (−125), ’sugar’ (−122), ’distribution of agricultural products to the most deprived persons’ (−102) and ‚olive oil’ (−100), were the main culprits.(6)

The underspent of the 1997 EAGGF‐Guarantee budget is around 300 Mio ECU (excluding the monetary reserve) and represent only 0.7 % of underspending. The underspent will be taken into consideration in and Amending and Rectifying Budget (AMB) which will be presented to the budgetary authority during 1998. The AMB will budgetize the non‐used credits of the 1997 financial year. This will result in a slightly lower contribution of the Member States, being the breakdown by Member States calculated according to the standard procedure.

Question No 61 by Allan Macartney (H−0266/98)

Subject: Brown rot in potatoes

Noting the recent extension of import controls by the European Commission on potatoes from Egypt because of the threat posed by brown rot, what assurances can the Commission offer Scottish farmers, whose seed potatoes have an excellent health record, that adequate measures are in place to prevent the spread of brown rot within the European Union?

Answer

Community measures to prevent brown rot in potatoes have been tightened up in recent years, as there have been repeated outbreaks of this disease and there has always been a risk of introducing it from third countries.

The Commission wishes to stress that since 1995 the Community's phytosanitary rules have required Member States to implement national programmes to eradicate brown rot in seed potato production. The Community has also adopted emergency aid measures to prevent the introduction of this disease into the Community. Furthermore, in 1997 the Commission submitted a proposal for a Council directive on combatting brown rot in potatoes, and Parliament approved this proposal at its December 1997 part‐session. This proposal has subsequently been amended to take account of the concerns expressed in Parliament's various amendments. Although the proposal is still being discussed in the Council, the Commission is confident that a successful outcome will be achieved under the UK Presidency.

Lastly, the emergency aid measures already taken to protect against the risks associated with third country imports have recently been strengthened. Egypt has been granted technical assistance to fight and monitor this disease.

The Commission believes that this combination of Community measures will provide adequate protection against introducing and spreading this disease.

Question No 65 by Mihail Papayannakis (H−0178/98)

Subject: Review of the Structural Funds

Does the Commission propose to use the regional development plans' 'environmental profile' as a dynamic means of achieving sustainable development, combining protection and enhancement of the environment with job creation?

Question No 66 by Miguel Arias Cañete (H−0265/98)

Subject: The new Structural Fund regulations and the environment

In the context of the reform of the various Structural Fund regulations, can the Commission state what provision is to be made for including sustainable development and the protection and improvement of the environment in the proposals for the new regulations?

Joint answer

The Commission's proposals for new Structural Funds regulations will take full account of the new Treaty provisions relating to the promotion of harmonious, balanced and sustainable development and the incorporation of the requirement of environmental protection into the definition and operation of the Funds.

At the same time, the approval of individual Structural Funds projects will continue to be the responsibility of the national and regional authorities.

The Commission will decide the package of new Regulations on 18 March and present it comprehensively to the public.

Question No 67 by Laura González Álvarez (H−0179/98)

Subject: Structural Funds

Will the Commission propose that the high biodiversity value of a region should be an eligibility criterion for Objective 2?

Answer

The basis for the new Objective 2 remains that outlined in the ‚Agenda 2000’ document which was published by the Commission in July 1997. The new Objective 2 is aimed at areas suffering from structural problems linked to changes in the industrial or service sectors, declining rural areas, urban districts in crisis and fisheries dependent areas.

The criteria of eligibility must identify the areas worst affected by such problems, taking account of the rate of unemployment, the level of industrial employment, the level and development of activity in agriculture and in the fishing industry and the degree of social exclusion. In these terms, the biodiversity of a region would not be an appropriate criterion for the identification of areas eligible for support.

At the same time, in the programmes for the eligible regions, the Commission fully recognizes the importance of sustainable development and, where appropriate, for measures which conserve and promote biodiversity as an important asset for economic and social development.

Question No 68 by Pedro Marset Campos (H−0180/98)

Subject: Structural Funds

Will the Commission guarantee that environmental authorities will be comprehensively involved not only in preparing Regional Development Plans but also in managing Community Support Frameworks, Operational Programmes and Projects?

Answer

The Commission agrees with Parliament about the important role environmental authorities play in ensuring sustainable development. Although the situation has already improved since the last reform of the Structural Funds' Regulations in 1993, their participation in the process is not yet comprehensive and satisfactory everywhere.

The question of how to improve the involvement of environmental authorities in the preparation and implementation of the programmes is therefore an issue being discussed in the preparation of the Commission's proposals for new regulations on the Structural Funds.

However, the organization of programme implementation is a matter for the Member States. The Regulations themselves cannot go beyond a certain level of detail here; and the precise way in which environmental authorities are participating in national and regional decision‐making will continue to be determined in the Member States.

Question No 69 by Giancarlo Ligabue (H−0186/98)

Subject: The serious situation in Venice

The question to the Commission concerns the situation which has arisen in the city of Venice as a result of the loss of the tax concessions referred to in Article 92(d) of the Treaty of Maastricht and the verification procedure applied by the European Union to the Italian Government. The continuing high water level and the constant migration from Venice in particular are causing an irreversible trend which will turn the city, within a short time, into a monument devoid of economic diversity. This loss would jeopardize its very survival and integrity. Since, Venice is part of our world heritage, as all the Community institutions have declared on several occasions, there is clearly an urgent need to adopt a strategy involving economic and legislative measures in harmony with those already laid down by the Italian State through appropriate special legislation. Venice, which has the greatest concentration of art in the world, belongs to everyone. Given, therefore, that Venice is an exceptionally valuable asset whose distinctive, unique and matchless environment also restricts its competitiveness, what measures does the Commission intend to take to protect and revitalize the city from the social and economic point of view?

Answer

The Commission is fully aware of the special position of Venice in terms of both its exceptional cultural heritage and its specific problems.

However, it is not the role of the Commission to initiate measures to safeguard this heritage and to promote socio‐economic development there. This responsibility lies with the national and/or regional authorities. The Commission is very willing to examine, within the terms of its existing instruments, any proposals made by those authorities.

However, it should be recognized that these instruments are limited in scope. In particular, the Community's Structural Funds cannot intervene to support infrastructure works or productive investments in the historic centre of the city, which is not an eligible zone under the regional Objectives of the Funds.

Question No 70 by Richard Corbett (H−0190/98)

Subject: Unacceptable delay in rolling forward unspent ESF appropriations from 1997 to 1998

Can the Commission explain the delay in the decision to roll forward unspent ESF appropriations from 1997 to 1998, in particular as regards the Merseyside Objective 1 region? Can it confirm that this is partly due to new Commission procedures, being introduced under the SEM2000 programme, whereby such decisions will no longer be taken by the services but by the college of Commissioners? Was not the intention of SEM2000 supposed to be simplifying rather than worsening bureaucratic procedures? If so, has the Commission not got it badly wrong in this instance? Is the Commission aware of the havoc that this delay causes among the weakest beneficiaries of ESF spending, such as community and voluntary organizations, and what measures does it intend to take to rectify the situation? Why did the Commission not use the opportunity of the Monitoring Committee of 29 January 1998 to warn of this impending disaster?

Answer

The delay referred to by the honourable Member was caused by the late submission by the Member State authorities of the full financial information necessary for the Commission to modify the Merseyside Objective 1 programme.

The Commission undertakes to perform modifications of this type, which confirm decisions of the Monitoring Committee, within a deadline of 20 working days of receiving the necessary information. In this case, the necessary information was received from the UK authorities on 30 January 1998. The Commission decision to confirm modifications of the Merseyside programme was adopted on 27 February 1998.

It is true that the Commission has been using, for almost two years now, a revised procedure for confirming programme modifications. This is not part of the SEM 2000 initiative, but the result of an earlier agreement adopted for legal reasons. Under this agreement all modifications to previous Commission decisions decided by Monitoring Committees must be confirmed by a Commission decision in accordance with Article 25(5) of Council Regulation (EEC No 4253/88 as amended(7) . These decisions are signed by a Member of the Commission without being put before a meeting of the Commission.

The Commission is aware of the difficulties which can be caused in the regions by the late payment of grant to project sponsors. Irrespective of ongoing administrative procedures, it is for the UK Government as implementing authority for the Merseyside programme to ensure timely transmission of grant payments to beneficiaries.

The Commission had made the implementing authority fully aware of the situation regarding this particular modification prior to the Objective 1 Monitoring Committee held in Merseyside on 29 January 1998. For this reason the Commission's representatives did not consider it necessary to raise the mater again at that meeting.

Question No 71 by Manuel Medina Ortega (H−0196/98)

Subject: REGIS programme

In view of the proposals concerning abolition of the REGIS programme for aid for the Union's most remote regions, what mechanisms does the Commission propose for the future organization of such aid? Will the existing level of aid for the most remote regions be maintained, at all events, over the period 2000‐2006?

Answer

The Commission intends to pay special attention to the most remote regions within the context of the revision of the Structural Funds. As the Commission's Agenda 2000 communication envisages, such regions will specifically come under Objective 1, even if their per capita GDP is higher than 75 % of the EC average.

As far as the actions undertaken until now within the scope of REGIS are concerned, the Commission proposes to incorporate these into the Objective 1 programmes, in order to concentrate the issues, simplify the management and administration of such actions, and finally, increase their effectiveness.

In terms of the degree of EC aid, the most remote regions should benefit, to the same extent as other regions eligible for Objective 1, from the attempt to concentrate budget resources in favour of Objective 1. The total amount of Structural Funds allocated to eligible regions under Objective 1 should, as it does now, represent approximately two thirds of the Structural Funds intended for the fifteen Member States. Furthermore, according to the Commission's guidelines, the criteria used to determine the amount of appropriations allocated to the most remote regions will be same as those used for all the regions eligible for Objective 1. These will be objective criteria comparable to those for the 1994‐1999 period. They include: eligible population; regional prosperity; national prosperity; and the relative gravity of structural problems, particularly the unemployment rate.

Question No 72 by Robin Teverson (H−0216/98)

Subject: Funding for rural areas

The Commission is expected to publish the draft regulations for the new Structural Funds next week. I would be grateful for the Commission's assurances that they will not penalize rural areas, such as those in the South West of England. Criteria based on population density rather than GDP would be unfairly weighted against the UK which has a high population but areas of severe poverty and economic decline. How does the Commission propose to ensure that poor rural areas will continue to receive the European funding they need to catch up with wealthier regions?

Answer

The Commission's proposals for the criteria to be used to determine the eligibility of regions for assistance under the Structural Funds will be based on the ‚Agenda 2000’. There, the Commission draws a clear distinction between the regions where development is lagging behind, which would be eligible under Objective 1, and other areas of the Community, including rural areas, that are seriously affected by economic restructuring, which would be eligible under Objective 2.

As at present, assistance under Objective 1 would be targeted on the regions with a low level of productive capacity and development as indicated by GDP per head. The GDP indicator is particularly well adapted to the larger NUTS level 2 regions covered by Objective 1 where commuter flows tend to be limited, so that the GDP generated within the region can be attributed to the resident population.

The new Objective 2, in accordance with ‚Agenda 2000’, would be targeted on smaller areas, typically located in the more developed Member States, which are seriously affected by problems indicated by ‚the rate of unemployment, the levels of industrial employment, the level and development of activity in agriculture and in the fishing industry, and of the degree of social exclusion’. The list of Objective 2 areas, including the rural areas, would be determined in partnership between the Commission and the Member States taking into account the national priorities. For regions where the situation has improved and which no longer meet the criteria, the Commission proposes phasing‐out arrangements.

Question No 73 by Jan Andersson (H−0217/98)

Subject: The Commission's intentions concerning structural aid to cities

Our European cities are today faced with a series of grave problems: high unemployment, social exclusion and growing segregation. Direct poverty is also on the increase in some city areas. There is every reason therefore for the EU through its structural funds, to pay great attention to the need of the cities for aid to enable them to tackle serious social problems more effectively. When aid is allocated it is important that not just the very largest cities should be granted such assistance but that 'smaller' cities facing the same type of problems should also be eligible.

How does the Commission intend to help ensure that the smaller cities also receive a share of the aid from the structural funds?

Question No 74 by Tommy Waidelich (H−0219/98)

Subject: The Commission's intentions concerning incorporation of an urban dimension in future structural aid

A debate is currently in progress on Agenda 2000 and the new structural fund aid. In November 1997 Parliament advocated the full incorporation of an urban dimension in the structural funds. It is important for unemployment and social exclusion to be combated regardless of whether the problems arise in urban or rural areas. Today, the greatest social problems are moreover encountered in the towns.

How does the Commission view the scope for incorporating the urban dimension in the new structural aid as well as the principle that unemployment and social exclusion ought to be tackled regardless of where the problems arose in purely geographical terms?

Joint answer

In accordance with its ideas set out in ‚Agenda 2000’, the Commission believes that the policies of the Community financed under the Structural Funds should retain an important urban dimension in the next programming period. It will continue to be possible to address the urban dimension under the Objective 1 programmes, while under the new Objective 2 the traditional support for industrialized urban areas will be supplemented by an additional focus on major urban areas experiencing multiple deprivation, whatever its cause. Objective 1 and 2 programmes will not only address the problems of social exclusion and segregation, but also seek to exploit the potential that cities offer for sustainable economic development and growth in regions that are lagging behind.

The programmes will also allow the situation of smaller towns and cities to be addressed. Outside the regional Objectives, the European Social Fund will continue to support human resource development and social inclusion.

Question No 75 by Birgitta Ahlqvist (H−0221/98)

Subject: Future support for Objective 6 regions

According to Agenda 2000, Objective 6 is to be incorporated into Objective 1, which seeks to promote development in regions where per capita GNP is 75 % of the EU average or less. This is not the case for existing Objective 6 regions and the Commission therefore refers to 'special arrangements'. It is important that Objective 6 should in the future also enjoy the same resources and status as today.

Can the Commission state whether population density will be a criterion, as its reply is of considerable significance for the sparsely populated areas in the North?

Answer

The Commission's communication ‚Agenda 2000’ stresses that eligibility under Objective 1 will be evaluated solely on the basis of per capita GDP. Only regions with a per capita GDP measured in terms of purchasing power at NUTS level II of less than 75 % of the EU average will be eligible under this Objective. Population density will not be taken into consideration in this context.

Northern regions where per capita GDP is less than 75 % of the EU average will be automatically eligible under Objective 1.

With regard to regions at present eligible under Objective 6, ’Agenda 2000’ indicates, as the Honourable Member points out, that they will ‚benefit from special arrangements’. For that reason, the Commission will propose that such regions be assimilated under Objective 1 and receive appropriate financial treatment.

Question No 76 by Konstantinos Hatzidakis (H−0226/98)

Subject: Delays in take‐up of appropriations in respect of various programmes under the CSF for Greece

Information released by the Greek Ministry for Economic Affairs indicates that, for the period up to the end of 1997, some of the programmes implemented within the framework of the Greek Community Support Framework (CSF) had very low takeup rates compared to the commitments undertaken. These include the programmes concerning postal services (0.8 %), tourism (11 %) and culture (17.6 %) (overall: 14.8 %) and health and social welfare (15 %).
Can the Commission give the reasons for the delays in each of the sectors mentioned above?

Answer

First of all, it is useful to remember that the level of take‐up of the whole Community Support Framework for Greece is 59 % of commitments and 42 % of payments compared with an EU average of 60 % and 45 % respectively. The Commission has the following information with regard to the delays in the Operational Programmes (OP) referred to by the Honourable Member in his question.

The ‚Postal Services’ Programme has been unable to start due to the delay by the Greek Postal Services Organization (ELTA) in meeting the conditions necessary for the execution of the OP, that is, the recruitment of an international consultant and the creation of a special unit for the implementation of projects. As the corresponding procedures have now almost been finalized, it is intended that the Monitoring Committee of the OP, which will hold a meeting on 1 April 1998, will examine the possibility of actually launching the programme.

The ‚Tourism and Culture’ Programme has also encountered launch problems. At the latest Monitoring Committee meeting, it was decided on the one hand to bring forward the adoption of appropriate measures and on the other hand, to reduce the total funding by the European Regional Development Fund by ECU 30 million. As far as the ‚Tourism’ part of the programme is concerned, a team of experts from the new ‚Management Organization Unit’ (MOU) will from now on reinforce the monitoring of the programme. The take‐up of the programme could therefore improve significantly in the near future.

The delay in the ‚Health and Social Welfare’ programme is in particular due to the slow completion of infrastructure projects. Here too, it is possible for foresee that the arrival of an MOU team could accelerate the implementation of the OP and the take‐up of credits.

Question No 77 by Anna Karamanou (H−0232/98)

Subject: Commission's management of 10 % Structural Fund reserve

The Commission has announced that it proposes to withhold, during the next financial period from 2000‐2006, 10 % of Structural Fund resources as a reserve, to be allocated to those Member States which are highly efficient in their take‐up rates and execution of projects.

What procedures will be used to ensure transparency and objectivity and on the basis of which specific criteria will the reserve be allocated?

What measures will be taken to ensure that the cohesion policy is not distorted and the agreements with the Member States not breached, given that the 10 % represents sufficient resources to undermine the fundamental objective of the Structural Funds unless they are allocated in the light of the economic situation of the countries concerned and with a view to bridging disparities in development?

Answer

Within the framework of Agenda 2000, the Commission has announced its intention to increase the efficiency of structural interventions.

The Commission considers that economic and social cohesion must be improved and reinforced in an effort to achieve both fairness and efficiency. The Commission therefore considers that it is necessary to introduce a stronger incentive than in the past to increase the efficiency of the financial resources to be used in respect of structural policies for the period 2000‐2006. The proposed performance reserve, whose aim is to mobilize all the players involved, so that they use all the financial resources available to them in the best interests of cohesion, therefore responds to that concern.

The Commission will shortly adopt the proposals for Regulations relating to the structural funds for the period 2000‐2006. Within this context, the principle and operating methods of the performance reserve will be determined. The proposals will be adopted in accordance with the procedures established in the Treaty, particularly Article 130D.

Question No 78 by Richard Howitt (H−0238/98)

Subject: Reform of Structural Fund regulations

Given the Commission's expressed wish to involve the European Parliament as fully as possible in the agreement of new Structural Fund regulations due to be published next week, and former Commissioner Millan's practice on this issue in the period 1992‐94, can it now inform the Parliament which legal base(s) it intends to recommend for parliamentary consultation on the different regulations or different aspects of the regulations? Can the Commission also confirm it still intends to integrate structural assistance required because of unemployment arising from the service sector in the proposed new Objective Two, and indicate its current thinking on how this may be achieved in relation to population coverage and possible criteria?

Answer

The decision procedures for the Structural Funds are those established in the Treaty. For the new General Regulation on the Structural Funds which will combine in a single text the former Framework and Coordination regulations, as well as for the new Cohesion Fund regulation, the procedure is one of assent by the Parliament. For the new European Regional Development Fund and European Social Fund regulations, the procedure is currently one of cooperation with the Parliament. In the Amsterdam Treaty revisions, which remain to be ratified, both of these regulations would be decided using the codecision procedure. For the new financial instrument for fisheries guidance regulation, as well as for the new European Agricultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund – Guarantee regulation which will provide for interventions within the new Objective 2 programmes, the procedure is one of consultation.

(In preparation for the various decisions concerned, the Commission proposes that an inter‐institutional dialogue should take place in order to ensure the most effective decision‐making with the fullest involvement of Parliament.)

The Commission will formally propose all of the regulations concerned to the Council and Parliament in mid‐March. This follows a period of discussion on the future of Community structural policies which began with the publication of the Cohesion Report in 1996 and the Agenda 2000 communication in 1997. Parliament has been fully involved at each phase.

The basis for the new Objective 2 of the structural funds which will be proposed by the Commission is that set out in Agenda 2000. This allows for areas to be assisted which are undergoing economic change in services. The Commission's proposals which are still under discussion, will therefore include criteria specifically addressing areas affected by restructuring in the service sector.

Question No 79 by Bernd Posselt (H−0244/98)

Subject: Euro‐regions including the Czech Republic

To what extent, and by what measures, has the Commission promoted the cross‐border Euro‐regions between the EU and the Czech Republic until now, and what are its current plans for these regions?

Answer

During the period 1994‐1999, the Commission is contributing, by means of the Structural Funds, towards the funding of measures in favour of the cross‐border Euro‐regions between Germany and the Czech Republic (CR) within the framework of two operational programmes (OPs), part of the Community initiative Interreg II.A, one for Saxony, the other for Bavaria.

The OP for Saxony (covered by Objective 1) incorporates a total contribution of ECU 149.436 million of Structural Funds compared with a total investment of ECU 220.044 million.

The OP for Bavaria (mainly covered by Objective 5b) incorporates a total contribution of ECU 16.8 million of Structural Funds compared with a total investment of ECU 42.202 million.

The Saxony authorities intend to allocate 85 % (ECU 187 million) of the credits to the regions adjoining the Czech Republic. The Euro‐regions of Neisse, Erzgebirge, Elbe/Labe and Egrensis may therefore benefit. In Bavaria, the credits will be allocated, in particular, to the Euro‐region Bayerischer Wald/Böhmischer Wald, including territories in the Czech Republic and Austria.

The Euro‐regions, or participants situated in the Euro‐regions, may submit projects with regard to all the measures covered by the OP and benefit directly or indirectly from almost the whole of the programme.

Please note that by means of the ‚Technical assistance’ measure in the OP for Saxony (total cost: ECU 6.351 million) and the ‚Promotion of the Euro‐regions’ measure in the OP for Bavaria (total cost: ECU 1.5 million), the Community is contributing, during the launch period, towards the operating costs of the secretariats of the Euro‐regions.

The future of cross‐border cooperation after 1999 will be decided within the framework of the new Structural Funds regulations, which will be adopted by the Commission on 18 March and immediately forwarded to the European Parliament.

Question No 81 by Edgar Schiedermeier (H−0163/98)

Subject: Language and comprehension problems on Commission inspection missions

In view of the statement by Mrs Bonino of the Commission in a letter addressed to me, according to which it is the practice, on inspection visits by the Commission's veterinary inspectors, for Member States and the Commission to agree to use the services of translators, does the Commission share my views that, in order to satisfy the legitimate right of the businesses inspected to information, a case could be made for using university‐trained interpreters (the costs to be borne by the Commission)? This also applies to translating the final reports into the language of the country in question.

Answer

Missions carried out by the Food and Veterinary Office are intended to monitor the manner in which the authorities of the Member States discharge their responsibilities under the relevant Community legislation.

Particularly for sensitive missions, the collaboration of SCIC (Common Service ‚Interpretation Conferences’) has been requested, but due to budgetary reasons this practice has been reduced to the minimum. With the future enlargement of the office the Commission will try to minimize these problems with the recruitment of new official having wider technical and linguistic skills.

Question No 82 by John Cushnahan (H−0166/98)

Subject: Trans‐European networks

In response to the European Parliament the Commission indicated that it would produce proposals designed to involve ports and rail freight terminals in TENs. What ports and rail terminals in the Mid‐West and South‐West of Ireland will be eligible for the so‐called 'projects of common interest' and what is the timetable for the implementation of these projects?

Answer

On 10 December 1997, The Commission adopted a proposal to amend Decision 1692/96/EC on Community guidelines for the development of the trans‐European transport network. This proposal aims to identify and emphasise the significance of seaports, inland ports and intermodal terminals for the development of intermodal transport and sustainable mobility in the trans‐European transport network. The main changes concern the integration of 300 seaports, 210 intermodal terminals and 35 inland ports in the outline plans of the Decision.

The references include all seaports which are open to commercial traffic and which handle more than 1 million tons of goods per annum and/or 200, 000 passengers. Ports which do not meet these volume criteria but which connect two or more transEuropean land‐links via maritime links are also included. Terminals and inland ports are included if they are located on the rail corridors or inland waterways of the existing combined transport outline plans and are equipped for intermodal traffic (containers, swapbodies etc.).

Where Ireland is concerned, the proposal includes the ports of Dublin, Dun Laoghaire, Rosslare, New Ross, Waterford, Cork, Foynes and Shannon. In addition, Dundalk, Dublin and Cork feature as intermodal rail terminals/transhipment areas. As with the entire trans‐European transport network, the implementation of projects, including timing, remains the responsibility of the Member States.

Question No 83 by Jaime Valdivielso de Cué (H−0174/98)

Subject: Employment

Given that employment is one of the Commission's priorities, will it say why it does not intend to carry out a specific action programme on employment as part of the general social action programme for the period 1998‐2000?

Answer

The Commission is indeed implementing a programme on employment. It is doing so by developing the coordinated strategy for employment referred to in Article 125 of the new Amsterdam Treaty, the advance implementation of which was agreed by the Heads of State and Government, at the Amsterdam European Council. This coordinated strategy involves four main areas.

First, the coordination of sound macroeconomic policies conducive to growth and employment throughout the Community in particular through Broad Economic Policy Guidelines.

Second, the Commission is assisting the action plan for the completion of the internal market. This will enable business and industry in the Community to take full advantage of the size of our internal market, and thus enable better growth in the markets for goods and services.

Third, the Commission assists Member States as they put into effect the employment guidelines agreed by the European Council last November. The Member States are drawing up National Action Plans which will be submitted to the Commission by mid‐April, and will be the subject of an initial assessment by the Commission in early May. This assessment will be discussed by the European Council on 15 June in Cardiff. The Commission will adopt a draft proposal for the 1999 Employment Guidelines by October 15, so that they can be approved by the European Council as its December session in Vienna.

Fourth, the Commission has started work on mainstreaming the objective of a high level of employment in the formulation and implementation of Community policies and activities as referred to in Article 127 paragraph 1 of the Amsterdam Treaty.

The Commission also considers that the resources of the Structural Funds, and in particular of the European Social Fund, should be used in a manner supportive of the coordinated strategy for employment. The review of the Structural Funds currently under way has had this objective in mind, and the Commission's proposals for revision of the Structural Funds Regulation [will] reflect this. Funds are also available for work connected to the Employment Strategy through the employment and labour market lines in the budget.

Question No 84 by Caroline Jackson (H−0182/98)

Subject: Italian steel subsidies

Can the Commission report on what conclusions it has reached on the possibility that state subsidies to the Italian steel industry are illegal, and what action the Commission intends to take?

Answer

The honourable Member's question is aimed at ascertaining what action the Commission intends to take with regard to any incompatible aid granted by Italy to its own steel firms.

The Commission can assure that it monitors development closely in order to ensure that its decisions are fully complied with, especially where, having declared public aid already granted to be incompatible with Community law, it has required the aid to be recovered by the Member State concerned.

That said, the Commission has to stress that most of the aid measures notified by Italy in the steel sector in recent years have been found compatible with the common market and have accordingly been authorised by the Commission.

There are at present only four cases concerning Italian steel firms in which the Commission has declared aid granted by Italy to be incompatible. Three of those cases involve insolvent firms which are in the process of being compulsorily wound up; the amounts of aid to be repaid have nevertheless been duly entered on the lists of claims against the firms concerned.

In the fourth case, which concerns the recovery of aid unduly paid by Italy to Acciaierie di Bolzano, following action by the Commission, Italy has suspended, as an offsetting measure, payment of another authorised aid of an equivalent amount to the same firm, pending a decision by the EC Court of Justice on the legal challenge which the firm has mounted against the Commission's negative decision.

Finally, there remains a case concerning the steel company Servola SpA, where the Commission decided to open proceedings against notified aid for the environmental protection. The Commission is currently examining both Italian government's and third parties' observations submitted to it in the context of the proceedings.

Question No 85 by Christine Crawley (H−0184/98)

Subject: Food products containing inedibles

Following the answer given by Mrs Bonino to Mr Phillip Whitehead on 26 September 1997 (E−2479/97) will the Commission instigate an analysis of the accidents from food products containing inedibles, reported across Member States through the European Home and Leisure Accidents Surveillance System (EHLASS)?

Given the death of a three‐year old girl in my constituency, from choking on a plastic foot of a Pink Panther model from a Kinder egg, would the Commission confirm whether or not Member States have responded to the Commission's request identified under points 1, 2 & 3 in its answer to Mr Whitehead's question.

If Member States have not responded, will the Commission be launching the procedure foreseen in articles 9‐11 of the General Product Safety Directive?

Answer

As things stand, the Commission does not intend to use the EHLASS system to carry out a more detailed analysis of accidents caused by inedible items mixed in with foodstuffs with no separate packaging. The data already available, the talks opened with the Member States in the emergency committee set up by the directive on general product safety (59/92/EEC) and the measures already taken to tackle this problem make further action unnecessary for the moment.

Following the answer given by the Commission to the question by Mr Whitehead (E−2479/97), the Member States have supplied the following additional information:

‐ all (with the exception of Greece and the Netherlands) have launched specific inquiries and issued instructions to their monitoring bodies with a view to identifying the products in question on their markets;

‐ the various measures taken to tackle the issue of inedible products mixed in with foodstuffs without separate packaging have shown that the articles in question are not or are no longer marketed in the Member States;

‐ finally, the Member States have made it clear that they have the instruments required to deal adequately in the future with the risks in question and that Commission action is not therefore required.

As things stand, therefore, the Commission does not intend to initiate the procedure provided for in Articles 9‐11 of the directive on general product safety. However, should the existing instruments prove inadequate, and should consideration need to be given to other means of ensuring that consumers enjoy a high level of protection, that solution would be one of those envisaged.

Question No 86 by Niels Kofoed (H−0193/98)

Subject: Compatibility between the office of Commissioner and taking sides in an internal dispute about the content of a Member State's legislation compared with EU provisions

According to the Danish newspaper Information of 4 February 1998 Danish Commissioner Ritt Bjerregaard has made a statement about a proposal put forward by the Danish Government for the new water environment plan and the corresponding proposals put forward by the Liberal and Conservative opposition parties. She says she considers the government line to have a far greater chance of gaining acceptance by the Commission than the two parties'. She has also made a statement about the two parties' stance on the plainly vague time limits in the EU nitrate directive, and her attitude is clearly negative.

Does the Commission President consider it to be compatible with the office of Commissioner for Ritt Bjerregaard to take sides in this way in an internal dispute during negotiations on the content of a Member State's legislation compared with EU provisions? Answer

The negotiations in Denmark on a clean‐water plan have to be seen against the background of the Commission's letter of 14 November 1997 concerning Denmark's compliance with the EU nitrates Directive (91/676/EEC). Question No 87 by Enrico Ferri (H−0198/98)

Subject: The inclusion of Community law as a subject in competitive examinations for recruitment to the legal profession

In its ruling No 170 of 1994 on Community regulations, the Italian Constitutional Court stated the principle of the 'direct applicability' of Community regulations. The binding nature of Community directives is mentioned in Article 189 of the Treaty of Rome, which means that the relevant provisions of national law simultaneously cease to be applicable. The Court of Justice in Luxembourg has precisely defined this idea in various judgements, above all the judgement of 24 March 1987. Since judges and legal experts in general are to be 'European', is the Commission willing to promote a directive aimed at making it compulsory to include Community law in university syllabuses and in the qualifying and competitive examinations which provide entry to the professions of solicitor, barrister, judge, notary and other legal professions?

Answer

The Commission wishes to point out that Article 126 of the EC Treaty states that Member States are responsible for the content and organization of their educational systems.

The Commission nevertheless considers that better knowledge of Community law by members of the legal professions would lead to better application of Community law, and consequently shares the Honourable Member's view that it should be included in university syllabuses leading to entry into the legal professions.

The Commission is moreover backing several projects, which aim to promote the study of Community law.

The Commission also supports Paragraph 16 of the resolution on the Fourteenth Report on the control of the application of Community law (Thors report) adopted by the European Parliament on 29 January 1998, which encourages the Member States to make the study of Community law compulsory for access to the legal professions.

Question No 88 by Brian Crowley (H−0200/98)

Subject: Wimbledon FC move to Dublin

The Commission has been consulted by Wimbledon FC Ltd about the conformity with the Treaty of Rome of its possible move to Dublin (stadium in Dublin and participation in the English Premier League) as well as about the possible infringement of Articles 85 and 86 of the EEC Treaty by the refusal of the Irish Federation (FAI) to allow such a project to take place.

On 9 February 1998, a UEFA press release stated its opposition to any move to play domestic football outside the national territory, reaffirmed the absolute territoriality of its football organization and that each national association is exclusively competent for its territory.

Does the Commission consider that it is the right of Wimbledon FC under Article 52 of the Treaty of Rome to locate its new stadium in Dublin while playing in the English Premier League and that the refusal of FAI and UEFA is contrary to European competition law?

Answer

As the honourable Member rightly mentioned, the Commission has been consulted by Wimbledon F.C. and the issue raised is under scrutiny. The Commission does not possess, at this stage, all the necessary information to give a complete opinion on the question presented by the honourable Member.

As the honourable Member knows the assessment of the compatibility of possible restrictive behaviour of professional sporting organisations with the EC competition rules can only be made in full knowledge of the facts in their correct economic context and taking into account the specific nature of the sector concerned. It seems at first sight that the organisation of national football leagues on a territorial basis is not related to the economic issues of this sport but to the very nature of the sport in question.

If the Commission were asked to take a formal position in this particular case it would have to examine the relevance of the above‐mentioned particularities and, if confirmed, whether the UEFA rules concerned are sporting rules not related with economic issues or whether they are rules that violate the EC Treaty provisions on freedom of establishment and on competition. In particular, given the lack of necessary information to assess the case on its merits, it is at present unclear whether the decisions of F.A.I. and UEFA fall under Article 85, paragraph 1 of the EC Treaty.

Question No 91 by José Valverde López (H−0211/98)

Subject: FAO concern at lack of coordination in veterinary monitoring

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has called upon the European Union to strengthen the systems it employs to prevent and monitor the transmission of diseases in the field of veterinary health. Likewise, the FAO has pointed out that unless rigorous measures are taken, devastating animal epidemics can be expected within the EU.

Instead of responding to this alarming situation by proposing that structures for coordination and effective monitoring be put in place, the European Commission has recently withdrawn its project to set up a European agency for veterinary inspection and monitoring.

Increasing the number of scientific committees will not divert from the need to establish a security and observation network to inject efficiency into prevention and monitoring systems at the local, regional and national levels, as well as within the EU as a whole.

What structural and organizational measures does the Commission intend to propose as a response to the FAO's concerns?

Answer

The Commission is aware of the press release entitled ‚Europe still threatened by animal epidemics – better disease control required’ made by the FAO, to which the honourable Member of Parliament appears to be referring. However this in general refers to Member States' veterinary services and structures which are crucial to the successful functioning of the single market.

The Commission is committed to the establishment of a well‐staffed and structured Food and Veterinary Office capable of carrying out veterinary and phytosanitary inspections as required by Community legislation. The withdrawal of the creation of an agency has not diminished this commitment and the advice received from the IGS was that on balance it would be preferable to retain the office within the Commission services. Question No 92 by Niall Andrews (H−0213/98)

Subject: Manufacturers' car prices, excluding taxes

According to the Commission's latest report on net car prices (tax excluded) in the Member States, Ireland is the second most expensive country for cars. Most manufacturers argue that currency movements are responsible for the price differentials in the EU.

Will the Commission state to what extent Irish customers have been in contact with the Commission about price differentials and other problems such as difficulties in purchasing right‐hand drive cars on less expensive continental markets and will it outline what the consumers' rights are in such cases?

Answer

The Commission has not been contacted by Irish consumers complaining about the car prices in Ireland or difficulties regarding the purchase of a right‐hand‐drive (RHD) car in mainland Europe.

The Commission's Regulation(11) for motor vehicle distribution is based on the following principles: the car manufacturers have to make RHD cars available to their official dealers in Mainland Europe for sale; a dealer within the Common Market may not reject a consumer's offer to buy, or ask for a higher price simply because the consumer is resident of another Member State. However, since it is normally in a dealer's interest to maximize sales, there is no right of the consumer or an obligation imposed on dealers to sell. The Regulation establishes furthermore the following elements favourable to a consumer resident in one Member State who wants to buy a motor vehicle, including RHD cars, in another Member State:

‐ The consumer can be requested to complete only the same documentation, and in the usual manner, as is normally and lawfully required of a consumer resident in the Member State where the vehicle is bought. Usually such documentation relates to the name and address of the consumer.

‐ The producer and all dealers should honour the guarantee and provide free servicing, vehicle recall work, and repair and maintenance services necessary for the safe and reliable functioning of the vehicle, irrespective of where and from whom in the Common Market the vehicle was purchased.

‐ The manufacturer, the supplier or another undertaking within the network who directly or indirectly restricts the freedom of final consumers, authorized intermediaries or authorized dealers to obtain a new motor vehicle from whichever authorized dealer they choose within the Common Market automatically loses the benefit of the exemption and as a consequence this manufacturer's whole distribution network is automatically void pursuant to Article 85(2) of the EC Treaty.

Question No 93 by James Fitzsimons (H−0215/98)

Subject: Chernobyl

Can the Commission provide an up‐to‐date assessment of the present situation regarding the nuclear complex at Chernobyl, the amount of EU finance allocated to date to Chernobyl, and what influence the EU can have at this stage in securing the rapid and permanent closure of Chernobyl?

Answer

The status of the four nuclear reactors at the Chernobyl site is the following: Units 1 and 2 have been taken out of operation and Unit 3 is temporarily stopped for urgent repairs, with a planned re‐start in April 1998. Unit 4 is the reactor destroyed by the 1986 accident. In addition to the reactors, the construction of facilities for the decommissioning of Units 1 to 3, financed by the European Community and the EBRD's Nuclear Safety Account, is in preparation, with the launch of tenders scheduled in the course of the year. The Chernobyl Shelter Fund, which will finance works on the Unit 4 sarcophagus, was constituted at the end of 1997 and the first projects have been tendered.

The Commission has so far committed some ECU 115 million to activities linked to the decommissioning of Chernobyl and the remediation of the consequences of the disaster. Of this amount, ecu 65 million have been committed to activities at the Chernobyl site itself, ECU 40 million have been committed to support for the Ukrainian power sector in the framework of the Memorandum of Understanding on the Closure of Chernobyl, including the preparation of the loans for the completion of reactors at Rovno and Khmelnitsky to western safety levels, and ECU 10 million have been committed for assistance to the Chernobyl‐affected areas of Ukraine, Belarus and Russia. In addition to this, US$100 million have been pledged toward the Chernobyl Shelter Fund and, pending the establishment of the requisite legal base, it is planned to commit ECU 50 million of this pledge in 1998. In this context, the Commission trusts that the European Parliament will be in a position to provide its opinion on the proposed Council Decision very soon.

The Commission, in concert with the G7, continues to press for the permanent closure of Chernobyl in accordance with the terms of the MoU. A key to success in this endeavour is the obtention of international financing, including from Euratom, for the completion of the units at Rovno and Khmelnitsky power stations. This is in turn very much linked to the reform of the Ukrainian power sector. Efforts are underway with the Commission's full support to achieve progress in this area.

Question No 94 by Lone Dybkjær (H−0225/98)

Subject: Involvement of Eu citizens in decision‐making process

In its answer to my Question No. 126 (H−0121/98), the Commission states that directives 'are to be implemented into national legislation, as is the case for all directives concerning food additives. Therefore, it is left to the Member States to determine how the obligations imposed by the directive are to be presented in the national legislative implementing measures.'

I should like to ask the Commission in this connection whether it is unaware of Parliament's legislative influence and, long before implementation into national legislation, that there must be debate at European level? Is the Commission also unaware that the Council of Ministers often has a mandate from the national parliaments or has in any event discussed the issues with them? Does the Commission actually mean that citizens should only be involved after decisions have been taken? Is that what is meant by all the talk about the 'involvement' of citizens in the Union, i.e. that they should only utter 'hallelujah'?

Answer

The Commission is very aware to the European Parliament's legislative role. It shares the Honourable Member's opinion that there should be a debate at the European level, long before a directive is transposed into national law. The debate takes place, in fact, when the proposal is examined by the European Parliament, which is elected by universal suffrage by the citizens, and by the Council, consisting of governments, which are responsible to their national parliaments.

The Commission itself, before it even submits an innovative proposal, encourages a public debate, in which every citizen can take part, by publishing Green Papers, White Papers, and communications, and it takes into consideration the remarks and observations it receives, when preparing legislative proposals. In that way, a Green Paper was published before the drafting of the proposal for a framework‐directive to control this area.

As far as the proposal amendment of Directive 95/2/EC is concerned, which is the subject of the Honourable Member's question, a debate took place in the European Parliament, at the first reading, during the sitting of 22 October 1997 and on 14 January 1998, the Commission adopted an amended proposal containing some of Parliament's amendments.

Question No 95 by Hadar Cars (H−0233/98)

Subject: Possible discrepancies in review of the acquis for different applicant countries

The review of EU legislation – known as the acquis – which the Commission has embarked upon with the countries applying for membership reportedly has different implications for those countries in the first group for negotiation (the five + one countries) and other applicants. It is alleged that the review of the acquis was not final for the latter group but would have to be repeated once the countries had qualified for direct negotiations for membership.

If this is true, the countries in the latter group will have been deprived of the opportunity of catching up with the countries in the first group, a prospect which was held out to them at the EU Summit held in Luxembourg in December 1997.

Will the Commission explain how matters stand in this respect?

Answer

The screening exercise will begin at the same time for all applicant countries. They have been invited to Brussels on the same date and will attend a common meeting to launch the screening process. Screening will be carried forward according to the particular situation of each country, taking into account whether it is entering into the formal process of negotiations or whether further preparations are required.

Question No 96 by Michael Tappin (H−0236/98)

Subject: Administrative costs of the research programmes

It has been stated – for example in the Annual Report of the Court of Auditors for 1996 – that the costs of preparing applications for assistance from the research programmes are very high; figures of an average ECU 50 000 per project have been quoted. In addition the Economist newspaper in its edition of 14 February 1998 states that the 'overhead costs' of research paid for by the EU are equivalent to 7 % of the money set aside for research grants.

Can the Commission confirm these figures and will it make proposals to reduce administrative costs both for applicants and for the EU budget?

Answer

The cost of preparing applications to the Community research and technological development (RTD) programmes varies very considerably depending on the size and complexity of the project, the number of partners from different Member States involved and the extent to which these partners have a history of collaborating on research issues. Studies have indicated that the principal costs involved in putting together such a proposal are connected with forming the multinational consortium, an essential element of the European added value of such projects.

Over the years, the Commission has developed a number of mechanisms to give help to potential proposers. These mechanisms include support to information and assistance networks in the Member States, the electronic information and partner search facilities offered by CORDIS and information days organised by the different programmes allowing potential proposers to seek partners. In addition, the Commission has put in place specific measures designed to help cut the cost of preparing proposals to small and medium sized enterprises, including funding of up to ecu 45, 000 in the form of ‚exploratory awards’ to help defray the cost of developing initial ideas into a full proposal. Overall, the cost of preparing project proposals does not appear to have been a deterrent to any groups of researchers, since the RTD programmes are still significantly oversubscribed. The Commission will continue to work at ways of reducing the costs of proposal submission to applicants.

The maximum costs for personnel and administration for the specific RTD programmes are laid down in the Council decisions adopting these programmes. These costs vary from year to year and between programmes, depending on the volume and nature of the activities managed, but currently average out at around 6.5 % of the total budget. The first indications from a comparative study of the administration costs of Community and other national and international RTD programmes show that the Commission's administrative costs are lower than almost all other international programmes and are in line with the lowest end of the range for national programmes. Over the years, despite the large increase in the volume of these activities, the Commission has made considerable efficiency gains in the administration of Community RTD programmes. It will continue to look for savings in this area in the future.
