Question No 97 by Michael Elliott (H−0237/98)

Subject: Animal welfare

Under Article 14 of Directive 93/119/EC(12) on the protection of animals at the time of slaughter and killing, the Commission may make on‐the‐spot checks to ensure uniform application of this Directive. In view of past investigations by animal welfare organizations which have clearly demonstrated that some Member States have not been enforcing all the welfare requirements of this Directive, will the Commission say how many on‐the‐spot checks were carried out in 1997 and is the Commission satisfied that there is uniform application of the provisions of this Directive throughout the European Union?

Answer

Within the overall framework of its mission programme, the Commission has regularly carried out visits to abattoirs in Member States to monitor compliance with the relevant Community hygiene legislation. During these visits the opportunity is also taken to carry out controls on the application of Directive 93/119/EEC.

However, during 1997, the extreme pressure of work, notably due to the BSE situation meant that it was not possible to maintain that programme.

A new programme for all Member States has been organised for abattoir visits to monitor hygiene standards, during which the welfare of animals at slaughter will be controlled. Animal Welfare will be included in these inspections.

Question No 98 by Francisco Sanz Fernández (H−0239/98)

Subject: Cooperation between the EU and Latin America and Asia in the field of education

In its recent Communication entitled 'Towards a Europe of knowledge' the Commission lays the foundations for Community education policy in the immediate future. Despite its interest and quality, it is surprising that in point 4, 'Targeted international cooperation' it omits (deliberately?) to mention cooperation in this field with some regions of the world, for example Latin America (the ALFA programme) or Asia, where the Commission has announced the launch of a new programme. Is the Commission perhaps forgetting that some Member States of the EU maintain special cultural and economic relations with these regions and is it also forgetting that the EU has cooperation agreements with those countries, which include cultural clauses, by virtue of which it is already developing measures of this kind? Can the Commission, and especially DG XXII, say what the reasons for this omission are? Did it really forget, or is it rather that the Commission is not interested in developing cooperation with these areas in the field of education? What cooperation measures in the field of education did DG XXII carry out with Latin American and Asian countries in 1997?

Answer

The Commission's communication ‚Towards a Europe of Knowledge’ is a working document intended to open the debate and to prepare the ground for the subsequent discussion on the new legal base that will carry forward into the future the Community activities in the fields of education, training and youth, currently implemented in the framework of the Socrates, Leonardo da Vinci and Youth for Europe III programmes.

As such, in the process of the discussion in the European Parliament and the Council this document will be enriched by the contributions stemming out of this debate. The Commission welcomes these contributions which will lead to a more solid foundation for the new legal base. In this respect the Commission appreciates the valuable reflections put forward by the Honourable Member.

Concerning cooperation with third countries, the objective of the Commission is, building upon the special traditional links that Member States maintain with certain regions in the world, to strengthen these links by encouraging the active participation of partners from the highest possible number of Member States to give them a complete European dimension that brings an added value to links established on a bilateral level.

The Commission is aware of the growing interest of many third countries to intensify cooperation with the Community in the areas of education, training and youth.

In this respect, the Commission considers as highly positive the demand created in these countries, reflecting the excellent reputation of the Community programmes in these areas.

It should be stressed that cooperation with third countries in these fields is also highly beneficial for the interest of the Community as it allows it to access to good practices and innovative developments taking place outside the Community.

These considerations guide Commission action to the extent that the human and financial resources at its disposal permit it.

Concerning cooperation activities with countries in Asia, last year the Commission organized two joint seminars with experts from the ASEAN countries in Naples and Helsinki, which provided an opportunity for furthering mutual awareness of the activities of both parties in the field of higher education and laid the foundations for the launching of a cooperation programme between universities in the Community and ASEAN.

Regarding Latin America, in November last year the Commission organized a joint seminar with the Mercosur countries and Chile, that made possible a first contact and evaluation of the activities implemented by both parties in the areas of education and vocational training. In the conclusions of the seminar both sides underlined the need to continue and to develop these contacts in the near future.

Question No 99 by Nuala Ahern (H−0242/98)

Subject: Radioactive contamination of pigeons at Sellafield

It was reported in the British media last month that pigeons contaminated with radioactivity were found near the Sellafield plant in Cumbria. The plant's owner/operators BNFL admitted that some of these 700 pigeons were radioactively contaminated due to roosting in old buildings at the plant which were not yet cleaned up.

Can the Commission say what assessment it has made of the possibility of species of birds with traditionally long‐range migration patterns becoming contaminated by visiting Sellafield and then transporting the radioactive contamination to other parts of Europe or further south during migration?

Answer

The Commission is aware of media reports concerning the detection of radioactivity from Sellafield in a flock of feral pigeons culled near the site. It is believed that this represents a local problem restricted to pigeons with a long‐term presence on the site. It is understood that efforts will be made to prevent any other species filling the niche created by the culling of the pigeon flock. In addition to checks on pigeons, it is understood that the relevant authorities in the United Kingdom are monitoring the levels of radioactivity in other species which may visit the site. The Commission has written to the United Kingdom authorities to seek further information. Although it is unlikely that migratory birds pick up and hence spread contamination, the United Kingdom authorities have been asked to consider this possibility in their assessment of the situation.

Question No 100 by Ioannis Theonas (H−0249/98)

Subject: Supporting audiovisual production in the smaller EU Member States

Audiovisual production in the smaller EU Member States is facing serious problems which are aggravated, inter alia, by structural infrastructure problems, a lack of funds and the special language situation. Present data indicate that these countries account for only a quarter or so of total funding under the MEDIA II programme. The situation is more serious in the new technologies sector where the lack of technical know‐how and funds has generated concern about the possible decline or even disappearance of the audiovisual sector in these countries.

Will the Commission say whether it intends to draw up new proposals, based on positive discrimination in favour of these countries as regards the allocation of resources, in order to strengthen audiovisual production in the smaller EU countries, maintain the cultural pluralism of the EU and ensure that these Member States are represented in European audiovisual production of the future, so that they are not crushed by competition and can maintain their position in the new digital environment?

Answer

The Commission is fully aware of the particular problems facing European audiovisual professionals from Member States with a low audiovisual production capacity and/or a restricted geographical and linguistic area.

Since the launching of the MEDIA II programme on 1 January 1996, the Commission has implemented a whole slate of positive discrimination mechanisms in favour of companies registered in countries with a low audiovisual production capacity.

Such measures have had a significant impact, and there is a high degree of participation from smaller Member States in the programme. As far as the future is concerned, the Commission and the delegates of the MEDIA Committee have opened an on‐going dialogue on the subject of Member States with a low audiovisual production capacity and have decided to launch a study in order to better assess whether and which new or specific initiatives are needed.

As far as the three strands of the MEDIA II programme are concerned, the results achieved so far are summarized hereafter:

DEVELOPMENT

As regards development, the Commission has implemented measures to foster the development of projects and companies. Competition for funding is particularly fierce, especially in relation to the project development loan scheme.

Notwithstanding, applications from the smaller Member States have a better chance of being selected than those submitted by their larger neighbours (they represent 30 % of projects selected against 25 % of applications).

The Commission also supports the development of companies as part of the Development branch of MEDIA II. This scheme includes supporting the writing of business plans by production companies. This is granted in the form of subsidies to companies from Member States and regions with a low audiovisual production capacity and loans to companies from smaller Member States. Here again, the figures show a high degree of participation: they account for 43 % of funding contracts awarded for the writing of a business plan and 34 % of company loan contracts.

TRAINING

The aim of MEDIA II in the training sector is to provide professionals from the European audiovisual industry with the knowhow and skills they need in order to take account of the European and international market.

The Commission supported 37 training initiatives in 1996 involving 204 partners and 32 training initiatives in 1997 involving 284 partners. By the end of 1997, these projects had attracted some 1000 participants, 42 % of which came from smaller Member States.

One of the cornerstones of MEDIA's strategy in the training sector is to support initiatives which follow through participants over a period of time and provide training on the basis of actual audiovisual projects. The aim of this is two‐fold: to improve the skills of participating professionals and to increase the chances of these projects going into development and then into production. It is interesting to note that, on 1 January 1998, 268 production projects which benefited from such training courses had gone into development and that some 45 % of these projects are being developed by companies based in Member States with a low audiovisual production capacity.

DISTRIBUTION

The general thrust of the Commission's action in the distribution area is market‐driven with the aim of improving the market position of European works particularly outside their territory of origin. Notwithstanding, an inherent ‚bias’ in favour of smaller territories and less‐used languages has been built into the support scheme in the various areas:

Thus, for example, the selective support scheme for film distribution is favourable to the smaller Member States both in terms of projects selected and the rate of selection of submitted projects. Over 1996 and 1997, 61 % of the contracts awarded went to distributors based in smaller territories. Furthermore, MEDIA support represented on average 42 % of the total costs incurred by beneficiaries in smaller Member States (as compared to 20 % for distributors in larger countries).

In the area of video and multimedia distribution, 60 % of the support awarded went to publishers/distributors established in smaller territories.

Finally, it should be stressed that support for dubbing and subtitling is granted in the form of a subsidy and not a loan.

Question No 101 by Mark Killilea (H−0255/98)

Subject: Construction Industry

The Commission has indicated(13) that it is exploring the expediency of preparing a communication on an examination of the key elements affecting the construction sector's competitiveness. When will it make its decision and does it consider that the introduction of the Euro will help competitiveness and, if so, in what ways?

Answer

1. On 4 November 1997, the Commission adopted a communication on the competitiveness of the construction industry(14) . The document analyses the main elements affecting the sector's competitiveness and proposes a series of recommendations for improvement. Four main strategic objectives are set forth:

a) to improve the quality both of technical specifications and of the whole production process;

b) to improve the regulatory framework in order to remove the barriers which jeopardize the operation of the single market;

c) to increase the level and quality of education and training and to improve working conditions;

d) to support research and development actions so that they lead to real innovations.

These four strategic objectives, and about sixty specific actions set forth in the communication, will be organized into a plan of action, which the Commission intends to develop with the Member States and industry.

2. The introduction of the Euro should on the whole be beneficial to the construction industry. Construction companies should in fact find it easier to enter the markets of the various Member States, which will encourage them to become more efficient and will increase their competitiveness at the international level.

The construction industry has already started to benefit from convergence of interest rates towards lower levels in the EC. The Stability and Growth Pact also guarantees that EMU will maintain budgetary discipline, which will ensure that interest rates remain low, and will therefore continue to stimulate demand in the construction industry, particularly in the housing sector. Furthermore, the margin for manoeuvre regained should make it possible to redirect public spending towards more productive uses, such as investment in infrastructure, another factor of the recovery of the construction industry. Finally, wider, deeper capital markets will offer more diversified instruments to potential investors in housing, buildings and infrastructure.

Question No 102 by Hugh McMahon (H−0258/98)

Subject: NUTS regime in the UK

Given the particular importance of NUTS III in determining eligibility of Objective 2 status in the UK, can the Commission give Parliament a progress report on its negotiations with the UK Government concerning the new NUTS regime?

Answer

In recent years, the UK has carried out an administrative reform at the local level, which affects NUTS levels I, III (partially) and IV. Further to the reform, in June 1997, the British Office for National Statistics (ONS) forwarded a request for the revision of NUTS levels I – IV to the Commission.

Since then, the Commission has worked in conjunction with the ONS on that amendment, in order to make it coherent with the basic principles of the European nomenclature (international comparability, compliance with administrative structures).

The work is about to be completed and should lead, in the next few weeks, to the publication of a new nomenclature in which the number of level IIIs should be increased from 65 to about 130.

Question No 103 by Eva Kjer Hansen (H−0259/98)

Subject: Age limit for admission to competitions

On what grounds has the Commission introduced an age limit of 35 for people wishing to sit a competition?

Will the Commission put an end to this highly discriminatory practice?

Answer

The European Commission is pleased to inform the Honourable Member that on 21 January 1998, it adopted the political principle that age limits would no longer be used in notices of competitions. At the same time, the Commission observed the need for the institutions to implement this principle by mutual agreement. The Commission has therefore adopted an intermediate solution by raising the age limit to 45 for new competitions for basic careers, starting immediately, like the system adopted, on 20 October 1997, by the Bureau of the European Parliament.

Question No 104 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−0262/98)

Subject: False certificates issued by the National Registration Organisation resulting in shipwrecks and loss of human life

The Greek National Registration Organisation is being prosecuted by the Greek judicial authorities for issuing false certificates of seaworthiness for the ill‐fated 'DYSTOS' for illicit profit, a move which cost many sailors their lives. This decision by the Greek justice system bears out the steady stream of allegations made by employees who have stressed that self‐regulation does not work and that shipowners cannot sit on the administration of this Organisation which has provided certificates for many vessels with serious problems, resulting in the loss of life of many sailors. This Registration Organisation has not even submitted an application for recognition by the AICS and is classified as a top priority for inspections in the USA.

Will the Commission say what measures it intends to take in order strictly to control these bodies in all the Member States of the Union – an approach it emphasizes in its reply to a previous question of 6 February 1997 (H−0099/97)(15) ‐ so that no more lives are lost, and what are the findings of the experts' visit to the National Registration Organisation which took place in April 1997?

Answer

According to Council Directive 94/57/EC, the Commission, together with the Committee set up under the directive, is obliged to monitor closely classification societies which have been recognized at Community level.

The Commission attaches great importance to this activity. Together with Member States, it has started to monitor the performance of recognized organizations on the basis of the criteria listed in the directive and of other elements, such as ship casualties and ship detention rates, when related to the responsibility of the relevant classification society.

If the results of the investigation carried out by the Greek authorities reveal evidence of the Hellenic Register of Shipping's responsibility, the tragic sinking of the Dystos may have relevance in the context of the performance criteria relating to classification societies and referred to above.

The visit to the Hellenic Register of Shipping by the Commission's experts in March 1997 was not related to the special case of the DYSTOS. It was carried out as part of the assessment of the conformity of the Hellenic Register of Shipping with the criteria listed in the Annex to the directive. The results of this assessment will be put to the Committee for decision during its next meeting.

Question No 105 by Christine Oddy (H−0269/98)

Subject: Cuba

What progress is the European Commission making in negotiating an aid and trade agreement with Cuba?

Answer

1. ‐ The common position of the European Union on Cuba, approved on 2 December 1996 and extended on 26 June and 8 December 1997, stipulates, in Article 4 and elsewhere, that the intensification of cooperation and the development of a dialogue with Cuba, to explore the possibility of future negotiation of a cooperation agreement with Cuba, depends on the progress of the Cuban authorities towards democracy.

2. ‐ As progress has not incontestably been made since the approval of the common position, and as the Council has given no other mandate to the Commission on the subject, the question of a cooperation agreement has not been discussed with the Cuban authorities in the meantime.

3. ‐ However, pursuant to the recommendations of the 2nd evaluation report on the common position approved by the Council on 8 December 1997, the Commission recently sent two task forces to Cuba, in order to:

a) study the development of economic reforms in Cuba, and if appropriate, formulate proposals for future EC support of such reforms;

b) evaluate the expediency of possible cooperation with regard to legal matters.

4. ‐ The results of these missions should contribute towards the debate on relations between the EU and Cuba.

5. ‐ As the Honourable Member knows, Cuba has officially submitted an application to the Secretariat of the ACP to become a member of the Lomé Convention.

Question No 106 by Ursula Stenzel (H−0270/98)

Subject: Structural Funds

In border areas of Austria eastward enlargement may bring some adjustment difficulties and greater pressure of competition. In its reply to an oral question 131. (H−0130/98)(16) the Commission held out the prospect of permitting some arrangements to take account of Austria's special geographical position. However, no answer was given to the question concerning measures of competition law which might aid structurally weak border areas in their process of adaptation. Can the Commission say what form such measures might take?

Answer

On 16 December 1997, the Commission adopted new guidelines relating to government regional aid. The guidelines include criteria for the establishment of maximum volumes of aid in regions eligible for regional aid.

The consequence of the guidelines will be a reduction in the volume of aid at present admissible in regions eligible for regional aid by virtue of Articles 92(3)(a) and 92(3)(c), which have common borders with regions eligible for regional aid by virtue of Article 92(3)(a), whose social and economic situations are comparable to those of the CEECs. On that basis of this provision, the Commission could accept higher volumes of aid in such regions than in other regions with comparable social and economic situations, which are not in the same situation as far as borders are concerned.

Question No 107 by Reinhard Rack (H−0024/98)

Subject: Announcement of another restricted competition for Austrians

Where Commission staffing at all levels is concerned, Austria is as yet under‐represented, proportionately, by comparison with other Member States. This can be explained by the fact that Austria has been a member of the European Union for a relatively short time, but the situation is highly unsatisfactory both for Austria in general and, in particular, for those Austrians who are keen to work in the European institutions. A special competition, restricted to Austrians, was held at one point, and the prospect was held out of another competition, for all employment grades, for EU citizens of Austrian nationality.

In this connection, will the Commission state whether another restricted competition will be announced, and if so, when.

Answer

All recruitment to permanent positions within the European institutions is normally carried out by means of open competitions. All interested candidates must first fulfil the admission criteria set out in the published announcement and they must then pass the written and oral exams, which are highly selective.

Within the framework of enlargement and with reference to Council Regulation 626/95 of 20 March 1995, the Commission has organized special competitions for Austrian nationals at all categories and grades. In particular, competitions at the A8 and A7/A6 level for young university graduates either with relatively little or without work experience have been successfully completed, filling the requisite reserve lists.

However, competitions for Austrians at the A5/A4 level produced only half of the number of laureates the Commission was seeking and there was a similar shortfall at B and C level. Therefore the Commission published in the Official Journal C 30 A of 28 January 1998 another A5/A4 competition together with competitions for Austrians at B5/B4 and C5/C4 level to cover certain deficit areas.

Apart from specific competitions for Austrians the Commission will organize in the near future several competitions at A8 and A6/A7 level open to nationals of all the Member States, as well as two competitions for translators (LA 7/LA 6) and assistant translators (LA 8) of German language. In addition recruitment for head of unit posts reserved for Austrian nationals is still ongoing.

Question No 108 by Mair Morgan (H−0038/98)

Subject: Low flying

What studies has the Commission undertaken to evaluate the environmental effects of low‐flying aircraft on humans, animals and crops?

Answer

As, following the principle of 'subsidiarity', low flying aircraft are usually controlled by national, local or regional authorities, the Commission does not have any studies.

Additionally, most low‐flying aircraft are leisure and military aircraft and are not covered by Community legislation.

Question No 109 by David Martin (H−0075/98)

Subject: Fifth Framework Programme of R&D – INCO‐DC (International Cooperation with Developing Countries)

Is the Commission aware that, although INCO‐DC and its predecessor STD (Science and Technology for Development) were considered the most cost‐effective programmes ever devised by the international community to deliver the very best of EU science to developing countries, changes in the procedure for application to the programme, coupled with the fact that the money available to European institutions barely covers employment of trained staff, are making participation very unattractive for EU scientists? What plans has the Commission to remedy these defects in the Fifth Framework Programme of R&D?

Answer

The Commission welcomes the recognition given to its current RTD programme for developing countries, INCO‐DC, and its predecessor STD (Science and Technology for Development).

The Commission concurs completely with the view that they are programmes which are and have been very cost effective and which have assisted not only in the delivery of the best of Community science to developing countries but also in delivering the best of developing countries' scientific know‐how to the EU.

Under the INCO‐DC and STD programmes the aim has been to facilitate cooperation between groups of scientists in the Community and in developing countries who are already actively researching solutions to developing country problems. This is undoubtedly the most cost‐effective way of implementing research programmes and of ensuring their relevance and the applicability of research results. Concerning the question regarding money for European institutions to employ staff, both INCO‐DC and STD have enabled Community universities and research institutes to recruit research fellows for the duration of projects under the respective programmes thereby facilitating the work of permanent salaried researchers and contributing significantly to the development of Community scientific personnel. The Commission is not aware that participation in INCODC is unattractive to Community scientists. On the contrary it appears that the programme has proven to be very attractive – nine times as many proposals are received as can be funded within the programme budget limits.

As regards procedures, no major changes have taken place. However, over successive programmes, there has been increased attention on focusing research priorities at regional level coupled with greater emphasis on relevance and potential impact of results, and on promoting cooperation between countries from the same region. In addition there has been a shift towards more equal partnership arrangements by encouraging greater involvement of developing country partners both quantitatively and qualitatively.

These changes have been widely recognized as improvements and can only benefit the partnerships, enhancing Community scientists' experience and international exposure.

For the fifth Framework Programme for RTD, the Commission intends not only to build on the experience gained in previous programmes, but also to ensure through enhanced dialogue, that the new cooperation carries forward the spirit of equity which is necessary to establishing sound, long‐term working relationships between the Community and its developing country partners.
